questions.text: A young patient presents with recurrent episodes of excruciating headache on the right side of her head, associated with tearing and redness of the right eye. The headaches last for 1-3 hours and occur once or twice a day at noontime, several weeks at a time. What is the likely diagnosis and best prophylactic treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient with a headache that occurs at the same time everyday with associated autonomic symptoms occuring in clusters is consistent with cluster headaches. Verapamil is the best prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches to reduce the frequency and severity of cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is characterized by severe, one-sided headaches that occur in clusters, often associated with autonomic symptoms, such as tearing, redness of the eye, runny nose and unilateral headache that typically lasts between 15 to 180 minutes. The important feature of this headache is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at the same hour each day. It is also associated with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen. 

The typical cluster headache patient has daily bouts of one to two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year; this is usually followed by a pain-free interval that averages a little less than 1 year.

Verapamil, which is a calcium channel block is the drug of choice for the long term prophylaxis of cluster headaches. 

For aborting an acute attack of cluster headache, subcutaneous sumatriptan (6 mg), a selective 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor agonist, is most effective. High-flow oxygen is also effective in the management of an acute attack. 100% oxygen at 10–12 L/min for 15–20 min is required as treatment. If injectable sumatriptan is unavailable, then high-flow oxygen is the next best treatment option (Option B).

Other options:
Options C and D: Migraine presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Avoidance of recognized triggers is helpful to avoid symptoms. The various drugs used to treat an acute attack of migraine are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, CGRP Receptor Antagonists (rimegepant), 5-HT1/F receptor agonists (lasmiditan), and dopamine receptor antagonists (domperidone). 

The drugs used in the prophylaxis include propranolol, valproate, topiramate and flunarizine.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image showing ice cream cone appearance is suggestive of acoustic neuroma. The recruitment phenomenon will not be seen in this condition. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

The recruitment phenomenon refers to the abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus become intolerable. 

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.
    MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other Options:

Option A: One of the earliest features of acoustic neuroma is the involvement of the trigeminal nerve, which leads to an absent corneal reflex.

Option B: When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Option D: Hitzelberger’s sign, which is the hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall when the tumor affects the sensory fibers of the facial nerve is seen.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and distension for the past 1 day. He has a prior history of diverticular disease. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan displayed below?

CT - computed tomography
questions.solution:
The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. A colonic perforation is the most likely diagnosis.

 

The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. In an elderly patient presenting with severe abdominal pain and distension, with a history of diverticulosis, a colonic perforation due to perforated diverticulitis is most likely. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

CT imaging is more sensitive and can detect even small amounts of gas in the peritoneal recesses.

Other options:

Option A: The interposition of the bowel, typically the colon, between the superior surface of the liver and the inferior surface of the right hemidiaphragm is denoted by the chilaiditi sign. This condition, known as pseudopneumoperitoneum, could potentially lead to unwarranted additional diagnostic procedures and treatment if misdiagnosed as pneumoperitoneum. Below is a CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Option B: Small bowel obstruction can also present with complaints of abdominal pain and distension. However, there would be an associated history of obstipation with multiple air-fluid levels on radiographic imaging and not pneumoperitoneum.

Option D: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum. Below is a CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A mother brings her son with complaints of him walking around his room in the middle of his sleep. During these episodes, the child is unresponsive with a blank facial expression, he eventually goes back to bed after half an hour. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: It is a type of NREM sleep arousal disorder
The condition usually worsens with age if untreated
The condition is worsened by sleep deprivation
The patient has no memory of the episode on awakening

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario where the child rises from bed and is unresponsive during these episodes is suggestive of somnambulism (sleepwalking). It is an NREM sleep arousal disorder that is common in children aged 4- 8 years and usually resolves after adolescence. (Option B)

Somnambulism occurs during NREM stages 3 and 4 which is represented by high-amplitude, slow delta waves. It is more commonly seen in children and tends to have a familial pattern. Sleep deprivation (option C), interruption of slow-wave sleep, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

Sleepwalking episodes may involve sitting up and attempting to walk or other semi-purposeful actions. Sleepwalkers have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication during these episodes. They may sometimes interact with the environment inappropriately, which may result in injury (eg, climbing out of a window). An individual who is sleepwalking is difficult to awaken. However, if successfully awakened, they will usually appear confused and have no memory of the episode (amnesia). (Option D)

Management involves reassurance and maintaining patient safety during the episodes.

questions.text: A child presents with hoarseness of voice and the image of the subsequent laryngoscopy is shown below. The patient has no other symptoms. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papillomas are benign tumours of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11) which is most likely acquired at birth from mothers who had vaginal HPV disease. 

They most commonly occur around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis) and involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It also involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. 

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculated with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy, CO2 laser excision or topical Cidofovir application.

Other options:

Option B and C: Angioedema can be IgE-mediated (also with itching and urticaria) or inherited (deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor) and is characterized by recurrent episodes of edema that may involve the larynx and cause hoarseness. Laryngoscopy would show diffuse edema of the larynx. Below is a non-contrast CT showing angioedema of the larynx.

Option D: Reinke's oedema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. The following image shows Reinke's edema.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV patient presents with a productive cough with blood-stained sputum, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest x-ray image is shown below.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an evening rise of temperature and productive cough for more than 2 weeks in an HIV patient and a chest x-ray image showing bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and cavity in the left apical region is highly suggestive of reactivation pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).

Pulmonary TB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Pulmonary TB due to exogenous (new infection) or endogenous (reactivation of a dormant primary lesion) infection in a sensitized individual is called post-primary or reactivation or secondary or adult-type TB.

The apical and posterior segments of the upper lobe and superior segments of the lower lobe are most commonly involved in post-primary TB due to increased ventilation in these segments than in the lower zones.

Patients often present with fever, productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, malaise, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

Investigations: 

  1. Sputum microscopy:
    • Ziehl-Neelsen staining - the presence of acid-fast bacilli
    • Auramine fluorescence staining
  2. Sputum culture:
    • Sold media (Lowenstein-Jensen medium) or liquid media (MGIT)
  3. Catridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CB-NAAT) is currently the first-line preferred diagnostic test.
  4. Radiograph imaging - Chest x-ray and CT chest 

Radiological findings include ill-defined opacification in the upper lobes, consolidation, collapse, and cavitation.

  1. Typically, the disease is parenchymal without nodal enlargement.
  2. Cavitation is a distinguishing feature of post-primary TB;
    • Typical cavities are thick-walled and irregular.
    • Air-fluid levels are uncommon in TB. The presence of air-fluid levels indicates superadded infections.
  3. Upper-lobe involvement with cavitation and the absence of lymphadenopathy distinguishes post-primary TB from primary TB.

Complications of pulmonary TB:

  • Massive hemoptysis
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Fibrosis/emphysema
  • Pleural effusion
  • Lung/pleural calcification 
  • Aspergilloma/chronic aspergillosis
  • Obstructive airways disease
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Bronchopleural fistula

The image below shows chest x-ray findings of a post-primary TB with a cavity (black arrows) in the right upper lobe and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates (white triangles) in the apical regions.

Option A:

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in TB, which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest x-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity. Monod sign refers to the air that surrounds an aspergilloma in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.

Images below show Chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Option C:

Loculated pleural effusion:

A pleural effusion is the excessive accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Loculated effusions occur most commonly in association with conditions that cause intense pleural inflammation, such as empyema, hemothorax, and tuberculosis. Fissural loculations mimic tumor tissue and are most commonly seen in congestive heart failure.

Patients present with typical pleuritic chest pain that increases on deep inspiration, coughing, sneezing, dyspnea, and a dry cough. Physical signs of loculated pleural effusion include reduced tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and diminished or absent breath sounds. Shifting dullness is absent in loculated effusions.

Chest x-ray shows blunting of the costophrenic and cardiophrenic angles. It also shows a homogenous opacity, which could be lateral or lamellar, mediastinal, apical, subpulmonic, or fissural (biconvex opacities). Loculated effusions are confirmed by lateral decubitus x-ray or USG.

The chest x-ray below shows a left-sided lamellar loculated pleural effusion.

Option D:

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii that is an opportunistic pathogen that is an important cause of pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with HIV infection, and follows a human-to-human transmission.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever, dyspnea, and cough that is usually non-productive. It ultimately results in respiratory distress and death.

Chest x-ray imaging shows a normal film if the disease is suspected early or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric. High-resolution CT shows ground-glass opacities.

X-ray images of two patients with PCP are given below.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: A patient with bipolar disorder on treatment with lithium presents with complaints of nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and confusion for the past few hours. She was started on chlorthalidone 2 weeks ago for hypertension. What is the most appropriate next step for management?

choices.text: Order a CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
This patient with a past history of bipolar disorder who was started on a new medication (chlorthalidone) now presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms with associated lethargy and confusion is suggestive of possible lithium toxicity. The best next step to guide management in such a patient would be to obtain a serum lithium level. 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management for bipolar disorder. Thiazide diuretics (eg, chlorthalidone) can cause a decrease in the renal clearance of lithium and lead to lithium toxicity. Other medications that can increase serum lithium levels include ACE inhibitors, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and metronidazole.

Neurologic (eg, lethargy, confusion, tremors, altered mental status, seizure) and gastrointestinal (eg, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) signs are common in cases of acute intoxication. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades: 

  • Mild intoxication: nausea, vomiting, coarse tremor, and fatigue (serum lithium concentration between 1.5-2.5 mEq/L)
  • Moderate intoxication: confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia (serum lithium concentration between 2.5-3.5 mEq/L)
  • Severe intoxication: Coma, seizures, hyperthermia, and hypotension (serum lithium concentration more than 3.5 mEq/L)

Mild overdoses can be managed supportively with hydration and monitoring, and hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for patients with severe intoxication and prominent signs of toxicity.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

questions.text: A diabetic patient who has developed chronic renal failure is prescribed a dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4) inhibitor. No dose adjustment was done. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that was most likely prescribed to this patient is linagliptin. It is a DPP-4 inhibitor that can be safely used in renal failure. It is mainly excreted through the hepatobiliary route.

DPP4 inhibitors are orally acting novel drugs that act by the incretin pathway and stimulate insulin secretion. These drugs have significantly lesser chances of hypoglycemic side effects. These drugs are mainly eliminated unchanged by the kidneys, except Linagliptin which is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route and is therefore considered relatively safer in a patient with renal failure.

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Dulaglutide is safe in renal failure, but it is a GLP-1 analog.

Option B: Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor but is excreted in the urine. The dose should be decreased in patients with renal failure.

Option D: Pramlintide is an amylin analog and can be used in moderate renal disease.

questions.text: A woman with a family history of breast cancer undergoes genetic screening and is found to be positive for BRCA1 mutation. Which of the following procedures should be suggested to this patient?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and mastectomy are offered in women with BRCA mutations as they have an increased risk of ovarian and breast cancers.

Salpingo-oophorectomy is ideally done between the ages of 35 to 40 for those with BRCA1 mutations but can be delayed up to 45 years for those with BRCA2 mutations. This procedure also reduces the risk of breast cancer in premenopausal women by decreasing hormonal stimulation of the breasts.

Bilateral mastectomy reduces the risk of breast cancer by 85-100%.

The risk can also be reduced with medical therapy. Combined oral contraceptives reduce the risk of ovarian cancer and tamoxifen or raloxifene reduces the risk of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a surgical modality of treatment for the given type of refractive error?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the rays of light falling in front of the retina. Such difference in optics is seen in myopia. Conductive keratoplasty is generally done for the management of hypermetropia and not myopia. 

The various surgeries done for myopia and hypermetropia are summed up in the pearls attached below. 

The term ametropia refers to conditions of refractive error while emmetropia refers to an optically normal eye.

Emmetropia is reserved for the state when the lens of the eye is relaxed and an object at infinity or at least at a distance greater than 6 meters is sharply focused on the retina and clearly visualized.

The term ametropia includes conditions such as

  • Myopia is the state when the retina is too far back
  • Hypermetropia  is the state when the retina is in front of the image formed
  • Astigmatism - Curvature ametropia can lead to a very troublesome error of refraction called astigmatism

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was started on an anticancer drug for the germ cell tumor of the testes. After 2 months he started developing the following skin lesions. Identify the anticancer drug:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a germ cell tumor of the testes and the image shows flagellate dermatitis. So, the anticancer drug is bleomycin.

Flagellate dermatitis is bands of pruritic, linear, and erythema maculae over the trunk and extremities. It can be associated with conditions such as dermatomyositis. It can also be seen as an adverse effect a few hours to 6 months after the administration of drugs like bleomycin, and peplomycin.

The rash of flagellate dermatitis heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. These lesions readily respond to topical corticosteroids, but usually, disappear after the stoppage of the drug. 

Bleomycin is DNA cleaving anticancer antibiotic that causes oxidative damage to nucleotides, resulting in single- and double-stranded breaks in DNA. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of testicular cancer and Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Bleomycin has a little myelosuppression effect. The major adverse events include dose-dependent pulmonary toxicity (irreversible pulmonary fibrosis) and flagellate dermatitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Oxaliplatin is an antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of colorectal cancer. The adverse events include peripheral neuropathy, leukemia, and pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Option D: Doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis.

questions.text: A woman, seeking revenge against a former partner, faked a pregnancy and later introduced a baby who was not born to her. Which of the following terms best describes the given scenario?
questions.solution:
In this given clinical scenario, this new-born is known as a supposititious child or fictitious child.

A supposititious child is also known as a fictitious child. In such cases, a woman pretends to be pregnant and substitutes a living child as her own, or may substitute a male child for her female child, or abortion. This is done with the intention of claiming property. This can be identified by verifying the signs of pregnancy and delivery in the woman and by DNA fingerprinting. 

Other Options:

Option A and C: In a spurious pregnancy (pseudocyesis, phantom pregnancy, and false pregnancy), a woman believes she is pregnant despite there being no actual pregnancy. It is a psychological disorder observed in infertile women, who have an intense desire for a child. These patients present with all subjective symptoms of pregnancy associated with an increase in the size of the abdomen. Obstetric examination and USG or immunological tests do not show any signs of pregnancy.

Option D: A posthumous child is a child born alive after the death of his or her father who was conceived before the death of the father.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with metabolic syndrome. Presence of which of the following additional symptoms in this patient constitutes a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on the NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: Blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

Note: 

NCEP: ATP III - National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III.

questions.text: A new complement inhibitor, CI-100, is being investigated for safety and efficacy in 300 patients with active vasculitis. The trial randomizes patients to receive either CI-100 or placebo. What phase is this trial currently in?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a randomized study to assess the safety and efficacy of the drug in 300 patients, which is conducted during phase 2 of the trial.

Phase 2 trials are designed to assess the efficacy and safety of a new drug in a larger group of patients (50 - 500). The primary goal of a phase 2 trial is to determine whether the new drug is effective in treating the target disease or condition.

Clinical trials are experimental studies involving humans that compare the therapeutic benefits of 2 or more treatment options, or of a particular treatment to a placebo. 

Other options:

Option A: Phase 1 where subjects (mostly about 10-100 healthy volunteers) are exposed to the lowest possible dose, increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose. The emphasis is to work out the safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous side effects.

Opiton C: Phase 3 involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug CI-100 in the question) or to the present standard of care (e.g., steroids as the first-line treatment of vasculitis). The aim is to establish the value of the drug in relation to existing therapy. If it is better than existing modalities, indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated.

Option D: Phase 4 involves postmarketing surveillance of patients after the treatment is approved. It is used to detect efficacy, rare or long-term adverse effects, and evaluate cost-effectiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is a constituent of the human lung surfactant?
questions.solution:
Dipalmitoyl lecithin/Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant.

In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

questions.text: While examining a patient with lymphoedema, you are unable to pinch the skin of the patient on the dorsum of the toes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
In lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. This sign is called Stemmer’s sign.

Other options:

Option B: Frank's sign is a diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backward from the tragus at a 45-degree angle across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle. It may be a predictor of coronary artery disease.

Option C: Levine's sign is when a patient hold a clenched fist over his/her chest to describe ischemic chest pain.

Option D: Winterbottom's sign is the posterior cervical lymphadenopathy that we observe in patients with african trypanosomiasis.

questions.text: What is the source of infection and infective form of Clonorchis sinensis for humans?
questions.solution:
The source of infection and infective form of Clonorchis sinensis is raw or undercooked fish containing the metacercaria larvae. 

Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke or oriental liver fluke) infection is endemic in South China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan, due to a longstanding tradition of consuming raw freshwater fish or shellfish containing encysted larvae (metacercariae). After ingestion, the larva excyst in the duodenum and enters the biliary tract. Here, it matures into adult worms. The eggs of adult worms are released into the bile ducts and carried to the intestinal tract. The embryonated eggs are then expelled with the feces. The life cycle is demonstrated below:

It infects the common bile duct and gallbladder. Infected patients can present with symptoms of right upper quadrant pain, biliary colic, diarrhea, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice. Chronic infection can be associated with cholelithiasis, malnutrition, and an increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma. 

Diagnosis involves the microscopic examination of stool for eggs. Investigations may reveal eosinophilia and an elevated alkaline phosphatase. The infection is treated with praziquantel.

Other options:

Option A: Freshwater containing cercaria is the source of infection of Schistosoma. The life cycle is demonstrated below:

Option B: Raw or undercooked fish containing the plerocercoid larva is the source of infection of Diphyllobothrium latum. The life cycle is demonstrated below:

Option D: Freshwater sources containing oocysts can be an infective form for various protozoal infections.

questions.text:
A young woman at 28 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of fever and jaundice for 1 week. She has no history of pale stools or pruritus. Investigations reveal the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Aminotransferases: 2500 IU/L
Total bilirubin : 8 mg/dl
Prothrombin time: 15 seconds
Hemoglobin: 13 g/dl
Platelet count: 100,000/mm3
D dimer: Normal
questions.solution:
Viral hepatitis in pregnancy is characterized by fever, very high aminotransferases, elevated total bilirubin, and markers of liver dysfunction such as elevated prothrombin time and thrombocytopenia. 

The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:

Other options:

Option B: AFLP (Acute fatty liver of pregnancy) is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. Patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Option C: HELLP is an acronym for hemolysis (H), elevated liver enzymes (EL), and low platelet count (LP). It usually occurs in patients with severe preeclampsia. The patients typically present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Hypertension and proteinuria are seen but may be absent in some cases.

Option D: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy occurs during the late 2nd and early 3rd trimesters. It usually presents with intense pruritus after 30 weeks of gestation over the palms and soles and is worse at night. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, dark urine, and pale stool.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presented with the triad of diarrhoea, dermatitis, and delayed mental development. She has a positive Obermeyer test. Which of the following would be seen in the urine?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of pellagra, and a positive Obermeyer test point to the possibility of Hartnup’s disease, which exhibits neutral aminoaciduria; the presence of excessive neutral amino acids in the urine. Neutral amino acids have a net neutral charge at physiological pH: alanine, asparagine, glycine, serine, and threonine. 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to the mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on chromosome 5. As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced, and this manifests as pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhoea, dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, thus distinguishing it from pellagra. Urine may also contain indican, which is produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Other options:

Option B: Branched-chain aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive branched-chain amino acids in the urine: leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Branched-chain aminoaciduria can be caused by: maple syrup urine disease, isovaleric acidemia, and methylmalonic acidemia.

Option C: Generalized aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive amounts of all amino acids in the urine. This can be caused by Fanconi syndrome, Lowe syndrome, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: Dibasic aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive amounts of basic amino acids in the urine. Basic amino acids are those that have a net positive charge at physiological pH: arginine, histidine, and lysine. Bibasic aminoaciduria can be caused by cystinuria and lysinuric protein intolerance.

questions.text: Which joint is not fused in triple arthrodesis done for CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus)?
questions.solution:
The tibio-talar joint is not fused in the triple arthrodesis done for CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus).

Triple arthrodesis consists of fusion of the three joints of the foot:

  • Talo-navicular joint
  • Talo-calcaneal joint 
  • Calcaneo-cuboid joint.

Triple arthrodesis is done after 10-12 years of age when there is complete skeletal maturation.

Before this age bones are not fully ossified, therefore fusion may not be adequate.

Of the three talo-navicular joint fusion is the most difficult to achieve.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A patient with asthma presents with worsening of her symptoms, despite treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. She also recently noticed blood in her sputum. Her chest X-ray was nonspecific and her CT chest is shown below. Serum aspergillus IgE is 1500 IU/mL. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with asthma with persistent symptoms, presenting with blood in sputum, elevated IgE levels, and opacities (gloved finger sign) in the CT scan most likely has allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). Systemic corticosteroids is the most appropriate drug for the treatment of ABPA.

Patients with ABPA and asthma are at a higher risk of serious complications, such as hemoptysis and respiratory failure. Therefore, it is important to treat these patients with systemic antinflammatory medications. 

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum aspergillus IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis. In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory compromise. 

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts or develop frank hemoptysis. The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific.

The use of systemic glucocorticoids is the first line in the management of ABPA, but the course should be tapered by 3-6 months. Amphotericin B and IV ceftriaxone are not useful for ABPA. (Option A and D)

Antifungal agents like itraconazole (Option B), voriconazole, and newer azoles can be used for over 4 months to control disease activity. However, this is only after steroids have been initiated to control the symptoms. Monoclonal antibodies against IgE, IL-4, and IL-5 receptors can be used for severe refractory cases.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing chronic dialysis?
questions.solution:
Cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis is the major cause of death in patients with ESRD on chronic dialysis.

Cardiovascular mortality is higher in dialysis patients compared to patients after transplantation.

questions.text: A woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb, as shown below. On examination, there is non-pitting edema associated with the thickening of the skin. Which type of biological transmission is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive unilateral lower limb edema, which is non-pitting and associated with thickening of the skin, is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. The microfilaria of the causative agent W. bancrofti undergoes cyclo-developmental biological transmission. 

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. It undergoes only developmental changes and no multiplication in the vector, known as cyclo-developmental transmission.

Epidemiological classification of vector-borne diseases by methods in which vectors are involved in the transmission and propagation of parasites : 

Mechanical transmission: Here, an arthropod carries the infectious agent by either crawling or flying or is excreted by the vector at the site of infection. The infectious organism does not undergo multiplication or development during its transmission by the vector.

Biological transmission: The vector serves as a site for development, multiplication, or both for the infectious agent. It is of three types :

  • Propagative
  • Cyclo-propagative
  • Cyclo-developmental

The image below demonstrates the life-cyle of Wuchereria bancrofti:

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A woman develops puerperal sepsis following a cesarean section. Which of the following antibiotics are indicated in empirical therapy?
questions.solution:
Polymicrobial antibiotic coverage is indicated in cases of puerperal sepsis from postpartum endometritis as they are mostly polymicrobial with a mixture of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Gentamicin and clindamycin are given empirically to patients with uncomplicated infections of the genital tract. Ampicillin is added if the patient has signs of sepsis or if enterococcal infection is suspected. Metronidazole is not indicated as an empirical therapy.

Infection of the genial tract has also been termed puerperal sepsis and includes endometritis, endo-myometritis, and endo-parametritis, and a combination of all is called pelvic cellulitis. However, routine use of antibiotic prophylaxis has now reduced the incidence of puerperal fever following cesarean delivery.

Other causes of puerperal fever include:

  • Urinary tract infection
  • Breast infection (abscess/mastitis)
  • Pelvic infection including septic pelvic thrombophlebitis
  • Respiratory infections

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with easy fatiguability and backache. He has had recurrent infections in the past 3 months. Reports showed hypercalcemia. His skull x-ray is  below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The given radiograph represents the multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. The incidence of multiple myeloma increases with age, and it is more commonly seen in males than in females.

Bone pain is the most common symptom and is due to the proliferation of tumor cells, stimulation of osteoclasts that destroy the bone, and inhibition of osteoblast cells that form new bone resulting in osteolytic lesions. Recurrent infections in multiple myeloma are due to hypogammaglobulinemia. Hypercalcemia results from the chronic mobilization of calcium from bones.

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder: (specifically CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance of <40 mL/min or serum creatinine level of >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level >20 g/L (2 mg/dL) below the lowest limit of normal or hemoglobin level of <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron-emission tomography (PET)/CT
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI that is at least 5 mm or greater in size

Option A - Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by multiple tiny, well-defined lucencies in the skull due to the resorption of trabecular bone, resulting in the salt and pepper appearance or pepper pot skull. The clinical features are mainly due to hypercalcemia and typically include anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, depression, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis can occur due to hypercalciuria. Joint symptoms occur due to chondrocalcinosis.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of middle phalanges - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • An atypical cyst-like lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor 

Option C - Paget's disease is characterized by excessive bone remodeling. Most cases are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally on a radiograph or a raised alkaline phosphatase level. The symptoms include pain and deformities of the bones and cranial nerve palsy due to compression. The characteristic skull radiographic finding is the presence of mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull, which is referred to as the cotton wool appearance. 

Other radiographic findings in Paget's disease:

  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Squaring of vertebra on lateral radiographs
  • Blade of grass appearance in long bones

Option D- Eosinophilic granuloma is a mild form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis and is characterized by abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells, with an abundance of eosinophils, neutrophils, and lymphocytes. It results in medullary bone resorption. It usually presents with pain and swelling in the affected area. Otitis media and mastoiditis occur if the calvarium is involved. Compression fractures and neurological symptoms occur in spinal involvement. The characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a beveled-edge appearance.

Other radiographic findings in eosinophilic granuloma:

  • Vertebra plana
  • Floating tooth in the mandible

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: Identify the type of cataract shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The cataract shown in the image is a morgagnian cataract which is identified by the presence of descent of the brown nucleus and emulsification of the cortex.

Morgagnian cataract is a form of hypermature senile cataract formed by liquefaction of the cortex and sinking of the dense nucleus to the bottom of the capsular bag. The liquefied cortex is milky, and the nucleus is usually seen as a brown mass limited above by a semicircular line. Changes in the position of the head cause alteration of the position of the nucleus.

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following units of population is considered for calculating the under-5 mortality rate?
questions.solution:
The under-5 mortality rate is calculated as a rate per 1000 live births.

The under-5 mortality rate is defined as the annual number of deaths of children under 5 years of age, expressed as a rate per 1000 live births. It is considered the best single indicator of social development and well-being. 

Recent analysis indicates that children from economically disadvantaged households face a two-fold higher likelihood of mortality before reaching the age of 5 years compared to their counterparts in wealthier households. Thus, the under-5 mortality rate also indirectly reflects the economic status of a country.

The primary causes of death among children under 5 encompass pneumonia, complications from preterm birth, intrapartum complications, neonatal sepsis, diarrhea, malaria, and injuries. The Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) strategy is designed to tackle these fundamental contributors to childhood mortality.

questions.text: The fetal ejection reflex, responsible for childbirth, is an example of?
questions.solution:
The fetal ejection reflex (Ferguson's reflex) is an example of a positive feedback mechanism. Positive feedback is a type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state. 

Ferguson's reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Oxytocin is released as the fetal head presses on the uterine cervix, which further enhances uterine contraction. This finally helps in the delivery of the fetus by facilitating fetal head descent. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.

Other examples where positive feedback plays an important role are:

  • Clotting of blood
  • Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  • LH Surge
  • Action potential
  • Shock

Other options:

Option A: Negative feedback consists of certain changes that affect a deficient or excessive variable to pull it back to a certain mean value to maintain homeostasis. Most processes in the body are under negative feedback. For example, an increase in gastric acids leading to a decrease in gastric secretion.

Option B: The feedforward mechanism responds to the anticipation of a change in a regulated variable. For example, when a meal is in the digestive tract, a feedforward mechanism increases the secretion of insulin that promotes the cellular uptake and storage of ingested nutrients.

Option C: The adaptive control mechanism refers to the delayed type of negative feedback mechanism. When the feedforward mechanism has an error, the correction is made by a retrospective feedback mechanism called the adaptive control mechanism.

questions.text: A newborn presents with a midline defect in the lower abdominal wall as shown below. Which of the following can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a midline defect situated in the lower abdominal region below the umbilicus with an exposed bladder is suggestive of ectopia vesicae/ bladder exstrophy. The condition can be associated with a bifid clitoris in females. 

Ectopia vesicae/ bladder exstrophy is a congenital abdominal wall defect wherein the bladder protrudes from the lower abdominal wall and its mucosa is exposed. This results in the separation of the pubic rami and the rectus muscles. 

The condition can be associated with complete epispadias with dorsal chordee, undescended testes, and inguinal hernias in males. Females may also have epispadias and separation of the two halves of the clitoris (bifid clitoris). The condition can be associated with rectal prolapse and short stature in both sexes.

Untreated exstrophy can cause urinary incontinence and is associated with an increased incidence of bladder cancer. Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia.

Other options: 

Trisomy 18 (option A), Wilms' tumor (option C), and meningomyelocele (option D) can be associated with omphalocele. Omphalocele is another congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the umbilicus causing herniation of the abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord. The herniated viscera is covered with peritoneum without any overlying skin. This condition can be associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which is associated with embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis that affects the sclera which is suggestive of Nevus of Ota.

It is usually affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye distributed along the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve (nevus fuscoceruleus ophthalmaxillaris). Most of the lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, and increase in size and number during the subsequent years. It is found to be common among females. It can be associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome and Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome. Bilateral nevus of Ota is associated with Mongolian spots.

Histopathology shows a large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes scattered among collagen bundles in the superficial dermis with extension into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue at times.

Management includes Q-switched lasers and cosmetic camouflage.

Complications include meningeal melanocytoma of the brain, and malignant melanoma involving the meninges, choroid, iris, or orbit. In some rare cases, cutaneous melanoma can develop.

Other options:

Option A: Nevus of Ito presents as a unilateral, bluish, hyperpigmented patch that affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest (nevus fuscoceruleus acromiodeltoideus).

Option B: Hypomelanosis of Ito is a genetic disorder of pigmentation, which is characterized by symmetrical hypopigmented streaks or macules or patches, mostly over the back.

Option D: Lentigo simplex is characterised by small pigmented patches with distinct boundaries surrounded by skin that appears normal. The lesions are light to dark brown or black macules that do not disappear after they emerge. Below is an image of a mild form of lentigo simplex.

A patient is brought with shortness of breath, nausea, and vomiting. He is drowsy and unable to provide history. Lab findings are given below. What is the most likely cause of these findings?

pH: 7.15
pCO2: 35 mmHg
PO2: 90 mmHg, 
HCO3-: 15 mEq/L
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl: 109 mEq/L 
K+: 4.5 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient has a high anion gap, and Uremia is the only possible option, as diarrhea, renal tubular acidosis and IV fluid excess result in a normal anion gap. 

Anion gap: 142 - (109+15) = 18 mEq/L -> High  [Normal anion gap = 8 - 10 mmol/L]

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap. (phosphate, sulfate, and hippurate) The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD: hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia and hypermagnesemia. Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen: 

  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Starvation
  • Renal failure
  • Poisoning: Salicylates, Methanol, Ethylene glycol


Normal anion gap acidosis is seen in:

  • Diarrhoea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Duodenal and jejuna loop
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Drug induced hyperkalemia: Potassium-sparing diuretics, trimethoprim, pentamidine, ACE-I's and ARB's, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, calcineurin inhibitors

Options A, B and C are causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is not a macrophage?
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned are macrophages except the dendritic cell which is a professional antigen-presenting cell.

Macrophages are the largest of the lymphoid cells which form a part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. They arise from progenitors in the yolk sac or fetal liver early in embryogenesis and migrate to various organs to persist as stable resident cells. In the bone marrow, the progenitor cells give rise to monocytes which enter the blood during inflammatory processes. According to the tissue location and function, the macrophages are named as: 

Macrophage Location
Kupffer cells Liver

Sinus histiocytes

 Spleen and lymph nodes

Microglial cells

 Central nervous system
Alveolar macrophages Lungs
Mesangial cells Kidney 


Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity. Macrophages that have phagocytosed microbes and protein antigens process the antigens and present peptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages also function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cell activation and efficiently phagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b. Phagocytosis is also done by dendritic cells, monocytes, and granulocytes like neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils.

Dendritic Cells (DCs) are antigen-presenting cells that are located at the common sites of entry of microbes and foreign antigens and in the interstitia of all tissues, where antigens may be produced. These are derived from bone marrow, a lineage different from macrophages and lymphocytes. They possess receptors like TLR (toll-like receptors) for capturing microbes and are recruited in large numbers to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, they present antigens to naive T cells with the help of MHC. 

Follicular dendritic cells (FDC) are present in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen and lymph nodes. They present antigens to B cells in the germinal center which in turn express highly affinitive antibodies and later mature into plasma cells or memory cells. Langerhans cells are immature dendritic cells seen within the epidermis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not likely to be a feature of a patient with vesicovaginal fistula?

choices.text: Presence of air bubbles in urine

questions.solution:
Patients with vesicovaginal fistula are unable to micturate as they suffer from constant urinary dribbling. This is due to the constant urinary dribbling which occurs leading to an absent micturition reflex and thus absence of the ability to micturate.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the bladder and the vagina. In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labour, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area.

Investigations to be performed include urine culture, ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and bladder, intravenous pyelography and methylene blue 3 swab test.

In the methylene blue swab test, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity. If the uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula. If the middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula. If the lowermost swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula. 

Vesicovaginal fistula is treated surgically. It can be attempted after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside and clear the infection. After this, the Latzko procedure can be performed. Here, the vaginal epithelium around the fistula is removed and the edges are approximated. The Chassar Moir technique can also be attempted. Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest and most common symptom in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common and earliest symptom in carcinoma rectum patients is the passage of fresh blood in or with stools.

Other symptoms include tenesmus, mucoid discharge, and altered bowel habits. The bleeding is usually bright red in colour and painless. It can be indistinguishable from haemorrhoidal bleeding, which is the most common differential diagnosis, particularly in younger patients.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  • Mucus drainage
  • Tenesmus
  • Early morning diarrhoea
  • Pain
  • Weight loss

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

Distant metastasis

questions.text: If Amobarbital is added to a suspension of isolated mitochondria that are actively respiring, what would happen to the rate of oxygen consumption?
questions.solution:
Amobarbital is a barbiturate that inhibits complex I of the mitochondrial electron transport chain. questions.text: All of the following conditions show the pattern of inheritance that corresponds to the pedigree chart below except:
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree chart is mitochondrial inheritance. Tuberous sclerosis is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not by mitochondrial inheritance. 

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance. The mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is completely derived from the ovum. Therefore, when the mother is affected and the father is normal, all their children will be affected. 

However, children will not be affected if they are born to a normal mother and an affected father. Only the daughters of the affected mother will further transmit the disease to the next generations.

 

 
Features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. The organs of the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys are affected as they are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon in which the individual has both wild-type and mutant type of mtDNA. 
  • Threshold effect is defined as a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA to be present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction to manifest the disease.
  • The expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ. This is because there is a variable distribution of the normal and mutant mtDNA to the cells.
