questions.text:
Given below is the procedure done under 'Nalgonda technique'. What is the purpose of this technique?
Add lime + alum
↓
Flocculation
↓
Sedimentation
↓
Filtration

choices.text: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth. It causes mottling of dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a  corroded appearance.
  • Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Option A: Controlled superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Option C: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine, in its crystalline form, is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours, and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Option D: Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand-picking.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth. Her pelvic ultrasound is shown below. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the ultrasound abdomen and pelvis showing neck­lace appearance are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Centchroman is not used in the treatment of this condition. 

Centchroman, also known as ormeloxifene, is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill. It offers a combination of weak estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic properties. It inhibits the implantation of the fertilized ovum. It is contraindicated during the first 6 months of lactation, PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, and cervical dysplasia.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)/ Stein-Leventhal syndrome is a multisystem disorder. It involves metabolic and endocrine dysfunctions that commonly occur among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when ≥20 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvements in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for follicle number has now been raised to 26 per ovary.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Medical management of PCOD includes Oral contraceptive pills to regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones. Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, thereby it decreases hyperinsulinemia. It also reduces the free and total testosterone and increases the sex hormone-binding globulin. It rectifies the root cause of the endocrine disturbance to restore ovulation and thereby improves the fertility rate. 

Many patients with PCOS struggle with infertility. The first-line treatment for ovulation induction is clomiphene citrate. Letrozole is given off-label in cases that are clomiphene resistant for infertility treatment.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as ____.
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue and weight loss. An image of her thyroid scan is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the thyroid scan showing a diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine and an enlarged size of the gland is suggestive of Grave’s disease.

A thyroid scan helps to differentiate between a hot nodule and a cold nodule. Thyroid nodules that absorb radioiodine are called hot nodules. These nodules produce excess thyroid hormones. Whereas, the thyroid nodules that do not absorb radioiodine are called cold nodules and they indicate non-functional nodules.

Appearance of thyroid scan in other thyroid disorders:

Multinodular goiter demonstrates multiple areas of both increased and decreased uptake of radioiodine, indicating the presence of both functioning and nonfunctioning nodules.

Toxic adenoma demonstrates a focal area of increased uptake of radioiodine.

Thyroiditis shows a decreased uptake of radioiodine due to follicle damage.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A tumor in the sella turcica is compressing the portal vessels and disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion of which of the following hormones is likely to increase?
questions.solution:
The secretion of prolactin is controlled by the prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH) also called dopamine, secreted by the hypothalamus.

Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. The effect of hypothalamic prolactin inhibiting hormone, dopamine, is normally greater than the effects of various hypothalamic peptides with prolactin-releasing activity. Since the PIH is unable to reach the pituitary because of the compression by the tumor, there is an increase in prolactin secretion.

But, obstruction of blood flow through the portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, GH, LH, and TSH.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents with a history of nasal congestion, nasal blockage, facial pain, and hyposmia for the past year. On rhinoscopic examination, polypoid lesions are observed, and a CT scan performed is as follows. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

FESS - Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of chronic rhinosinusitis along with the presence of sinonasal polyposis, and CT findings of differential hyperattenuating areas within the sinuses point towards a diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis. Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is the treatment of choice for this condition.

Allergic fungal sinusitis is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. It is prevalent in both immunocompetent as well as immunocompromised hosts. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. The CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion. Treatment includes endoscopic surgical drainage. 

Steroids also must be administered pre and post-operatively. Antifungals are usually not required. Antifungals are required only in cases of very severe disease that does not respond to surgical treatment.

Organisms that cause fungal sinusitis include:  

  • Aspergillus (m/c)
  • Mucormycosis
  • Candida
  • Penicillium species

Bent and Kuhn proposed the diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis, which is considered the standard diagnostic criteria. This includes:

Major criteria Minor criteria
Type I hypersensitivity  Asthma
Nasal polyposis Unilateral disease
Characteristic CT findings Bone erosion
Eosinophilic mucin without invasion Fungal cultures
Positive fungal stain Charcot-Leyden crystals
  Serum eosinophilia

All the major criteria must be met by the patient while the minor criteria serve to support the diagnosis and describe individual patients.

Related Pearl: Indications of FESS

Indications

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis)
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polypi
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Endoscopic septoplasty

Advanced nasal endoscopic techniques

  • Removal of benign tumours, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas.
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia.

questions.text: A child with minimal change nephrotic syndrome achieves remission while being treated with oral prednisone. However, generalized edema and 3+ urine proteinuria re-occur within 2 weeks of steroid discontinuation. Which of the following best describes this clinical course?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child having a relapse of edema and 3+ urine proteinuria within 2 weeks of steroid discontinuation is best described as having steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome.

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by nephrotic range proteinuria of >3.5 g/24hr or urine protein: creatinine ratio of > 2. It is associated with a triad of 

  • hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL),
  • edema, and
  • hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL). 

Nephrotic syndrome in children is primarily idiopathic, with minimal change nephrotic syndrome (MCNS) accounting for the majority of the total cases.

The majority of children respond to corticosteroid therapy, making it the mainstay of treatment. Initial management involves a daily dose of oral prednisone or prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day to a maximum of 60 mg daily for 4 to 6 weeks. It is followed by an alternate-day regimen of oral prednisone for 2 to 5 months, with a gradual tapering of the dose. 

Relapse of nephrotic syndrome is defined as an increase in the first-morning urine protein: creatinine ratio > 0.2 or reading of 2+ urine protein and higher for 3 consecutive days. Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of discontinuation is defined as steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. 

Other options:

Option A: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as the inability to induce remission within 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy.

Option B: Frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome is two or more relapses within 6 months of initial therapy or four relapses in a year.

Option D: Secondary nephrotic syndrome occurs secondary to other systemic diseases or infections. Nephrotic syndrome has been associated with infections like hepatitis B & C, HIV, and malaria. It can also occur secondary to other glomerular diseases like membranous nephropathy and lupus nephritis.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A young woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. Her cervical mucus sample shows the following appearance on microscopy. She had her menstrual period 22 days ago. Which of the following inferences can be drawn from this finding?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
The woman is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The presence of a fern pattern on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperms. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern. After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise, and this hormone thickens the cervical mucus. The ferning pattern will no more be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

 The tests for ovulation are:

  • The body temperature decreases during ovulation by 1/2°F. Thereafter, it increases by 1/2 to 1°F due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.
  • Endometrial biopsy is usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 
  • Fern test- Appearance of fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.
  • Ultrasound- It is used to monitor the maturation of the Graafian follicle and ovulation.

Hormonal studies

  • Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred.
  • Determining the LH surge by urine or blood levels.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male patient diagnosed with malaria was commenced on an anti-malarial drug. After two days, port wine-colored urine was noted. His lab reports are given below. What is your diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9.0 g/dL
Blood glucose - 100 mg/dL
Serum creatinine - 5.6 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with malaria treated with an anti-malarial drug (likely quinine) developing hemoglobinuria (port-wine stained urine), hemolysis (reduced hemoglobin), and renal failure (increased creatinine) is suggestive of blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever (malarial hemoglobinuria) is an autoimmune process seen in Falciparum malaria, particularly in patients who have experienced repeated past infections and inadequate treatment with quinine. Clinical manifestations include fever, prostration, hemoglobinuria, and bilious vomiting, with the passage of dark red or blackish urine. 

It is due to massive intravascular hemolysis caused by anti-erythrocyte antibodies, leading to massive absorption of hemoglobin by the renal tubules (hemoglobinuric nephrosis), producing blackwater fever. Complications of blackwater fever include renal failure, acute liver failure, and circulatory collapse. 

Complications of Falciparum malaria include:

  • Cerebral malaria
  • Algid malaria
  • Septicemic malaria
  • Blackwater fever
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia (glucose <40 mg/dL)
  • Severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL, PCV <15%)
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Shock
  • Bleeding disturbances

Other options:

Option A: Septicemic malaria is characterized by high continuous fever with the dissemination of the parasite to various organs, leading to multiorgan failure.

Option B: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D: Cerebral malaria is manifested by features of diffuse symmetric encephalopathy like headache, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, slowly lapsing into a coma.

questions.text: What is the effect of epinephrine on enzymes of glycogen metabolism?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine increases glycogenolysis, and thus, its effect is to phosphorylate and activate glycogen phosphorylase. 

Epinephrine and glucagon have three effects due to cAMP-mediated activation of protein kinase A as follows:

  • Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase and thus inactive it to "b" form
  • Phosphorylation of protein phosphatase 1 inhibitor and thus activate it
  • Phosphorylation of phosphorylase kinase and active it, which in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase

The rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

The process of phosphorolytic cleavage of the α1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield single units of glucose 1-phosphate is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as the coenzyme. The phosphate group is catalytically active. There are different isoenzymes of glycogen phosphorylase in the liver, muscle, and brain.

questions.text: Which among the following is an intravenous iron preparation?
questions.solution:
Ferrous sucrose or iron sucrose is an IV preparation of parenteral iron.

  • Iron sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion
  • Safe with fewer adverse events – adverse effects are virtually unknown
  • Does not require a test dose

Other options:

Option A. Ferrous ascorbate – Oral preparation

Option B. Iron sorbitol – IM preparation

Option D. Iron polymaltose – IM preparation

Other preparations of iron :

  • Iron dextran - Both IM and IV
  • Ferric carboxymaltose - IV

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Kehr’s sign?

choices.text: It is an example of referred pain
It can be elicited in a patient with splenic injury
It is associated with pain at the tip of the right shoulder

questions.solution:
Kehr sign refers to the clinical sign of pain in the tip of the left shoulder elicited on applying pressure to the left hypochondrium, or elevating the left leg. It occurs due to diaphragmatic irritation due to hemoperitoneum following splenic injury. It is an example of referred pain from the diaphragm to the tip of the left shoulder via the C3, C4, C5 nerve roots. 

Clinically, a patient may complain of pain that is not present at only one site. Movement of pain is differentiated as follows:

Radiating pain: where the pain at the original site persists but the patient feels pain extending from that site to another location. Eg - sciatica pain radiates from the lower back down to the back of the leg.

Referred pain: where pain is not felt at the site of the cause, but felt elsewhere due to a common nerve supply. Eg - pain in the tip of the left shoulder in diaphragmatic injury

Migrating or Shifting pain: where the initial pain is at one location, but later the patient feels the pain elsewhere. The inciting cause is usually the same but there may have been some progress in the disease pathophysiology. Eg - in acute appendicitis, initial peri-umbilical pain moves to the right iliac fossa due to peritoneal inflammation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who is a known smoker presents with buttock claudication and impotence. On examination, distal lower limb pulses are absent. At which level is the pathology likely to be?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient with buttock claudication and impotence is suggestive of Leriche Syndrome, which is an arterial occlussive disease occuring at the aorto-iliac junction (marked '1'). Given below is an image depicting the same.

Relationship of clinical findings to the site of disease
Aortoiliac obstruction Claudication in buttocks, thighs and calves
  Femoral and distal pulses absent in both limbs
  Bruit over the aortoiliac region
Iliac obstruction  Unilateral claudication in the thigh and calf and sometimes the buttock
  Bruit over the iliac region
  Unilateral absence of femoral and distal pulses
Femoropopliteal obstruction Unilateral claudication in the calf
  Femoral pulse palpable with absent unilateral distal pulses
Distal obstruction Femoral and popliteal pulses are palpable
  Ankle pulses absent
  Claudication in calf and foot

Investigations that aid in the diagnosis of this condition include Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, ankle-brachial pressure index, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA). 

Management is by exercise, smoking cessation, control of diabetes, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as statins and clopidogrel or aspirin can be initated. Surgical management  options include transluminal angioplasty and stenting or bypass grafting.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes of the liver is upregulated in the well-fed state?
questions.solution:
Fatty acid synthase is upregulated in the liver in the well-fed state. In the well-fed state, there is upregulation of metabolic pathways such as fatty acid synthesis, glycogen synthesis and protein synthesis. 

Fatty acids are synthesized by the fatty acid synthase enzyme complex. The individual enzymes required for fatty acid synthesis are linked in this multienzyme polypeptide complex that consists of an acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACP contains vitamin B5/pantothenic acid. Fatty acid synthase is upregulated by insulin and is downregulated by glucagon and palmitate.

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrate and palmitate is the end product.

Other options:

Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase is involved in glycogen breakdown and is upregulated in starvation.

Option B: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I is involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids and is upregulated in starvation. 

Option C: Protein kinase A is a downstream protein in multiple G-protein coupled receptor pathways and is involved in glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis and is upregulated in starvation. 

Related Pearl: Fatty Acid Synthesis Pathway

Reactions

Activation

Acetyl-CoA carboxylation

Elongation

The malonyl-CoA pathway

Condensation step 

Covalent linking of acetyl-CoA and Malonyl-CoA (with the release of CoA and carbon dioxide)

Reduction step 

Acetoacetyl-ACP to ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP (using up one NADPH2)

Dehydration step 

ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP to crotonyl-ACP (with the release of a water molecule)

Another reduction step

Crotonyl-ACP to butryl-ACP (using up a second NADPH2)

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, memory loss, and agitation. On examination, he is disoriented and horizontal nystagmus is noted. Which of the following enzyme markers can aid the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
The features of confusion, memory loss, and horizontal nystagmus in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused due to deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). This can be diagnosed by erythrocyte transketolase assay.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin, required for carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is its coenzyme form and is required for the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase 
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

Beriberi - anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness, peripheral neuropathy, and weakness (dry beriberi) or with cardiovascular features like edema, palpitations, breathlessness, distended neck veins (wet beriberi)

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with chronic alcohol abuse which lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

Korsakoff's syndrome is a neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by confabulation and memory defects. Immediate memory is generally maintained but short-term memory is diminished.

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: In children and adolescents treated with an SSRI, there appears to be an increased risk of particular ideations. Clinicians are therefore advised to remain vigilant of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used carefully in the young for the management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. In children and adolescents, there appears to be a slightly increased risk of suicidal ideations and attempts, but not of completed suicide.

Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRIs and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who gave birth 5 days ago presents with bilateral breast pain and heaviness while breastfeeding her newborn. On examination, she is afebrile, her breasts are firm and swollen. Which of the following management options would be best suited to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with bilateral breast pain and firm and swollen breasts on examination with no fever makes a diagnosis of breast engorgement likely. Breastfeeding should be continued in patients suspected to have breast engorgement, which usually occurs on the third or fourth day postpartum.

Breast engorgement occurs due to increased normal venous and lymphatic engorgement of the breasts which occurs before lactation. This prevents the escape of milk from the lacteal system. This is more common in primiparous women. It usually occurs after the milk secretion starts on the third or fourth day postpartum and presents as pain and feeling of tenseness or heaviness in both breasts, generalized malaise and painful breastfeeding.

Management includes breast support with a binder or brassiere, frequent suckling, manual expression of any remaining milk after each feed and analgesics for pain.

Other options:

Option A: Dicloxacillin is indicated for acute mastitis which is characterized by severe breast pain, fever with chills, headache, nausea, tender swelling in one quadrant, red, hot, and flushed overlying skin. This patient has only firmness and swelling without any signs of inflammation making mastitis unlikely.  Additionally, mastitis usually occurs unilaterally, during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum.

Option D: Breast abscess is usually suspected when there is no response to treatment for mastitis in 48-72 hours. It is also characterized by brawny oedema over the affected area, the onset of fluctuation, and swinging temperature. Management includes incision and drainage of the abscess under general anaesthesia with the incision along Langer's lines. Newer modalities include sonography-guided needle aspiration under local anaesthesia. Antibiotics and pumping of the affected breast are also done.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been drinking rum almost daily for the last 10 years. He comes to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting blood. His abdomen is distended. The doctor administers a vasopressin analogue. Which second messenger system does this drug act through?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal varices. Vasopressin analogues used in the management of esophageal varices to reduce bleeding act through the V1A receptor on vascular smooth muscle via phospholipase C.  

Vasopressin mediates its effect via 3 kinds of receptors- V1a, V1b and V2. All three receptors are G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs). 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gi, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

  1. Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.
  2. Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.
  3. Go causes Ca2+ channel inactivation.

Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

The image given below shows the effects of phospholipase C after activation by Gq.

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral hearing loss. His MRI showed bilateral solid lesions with ice-cream cone appearance.  A biopsy of the lesion is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the histological image showing Verocay bodies suggest the diagnosis of a schwannoma. MRI had shown bilateral solid lesions with an ice-cream cone appearance that is typical of bilateral schwannomas seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2.

This is due to a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that leads to the loss of expression of the protein Merlin.  Microscopically, they are compromised of dense and loose areas called Antoni A and Antoni B respectively.

Antoni A is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

 

MRI shows left bilateral cerebellopontine (CP) angle mass causing widening of the porous acousticus. The mass is seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). Bilateral acoustic schwannomas are strongly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

Acoustic neuromas are the most common CP angle tumours. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle (path of least resistance) leads to its characteristic ice-cream cone appearance.

 

Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome of 2 types:

NF1 (von Recklinghausen disease)- Mutation on chromosome 17

2 or more of the following should be present:

  • 6 or more café-au-lait spots
  • 2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuroma
  • Freckling in the axillary or inguinal region 
  • 2 or more Lisch nodules
  • Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone
  • A first degree relative with NF1
  • Optic gliomas

NF2 (Central neurofibromatosis)- Mutation on chromosome 22

It predisposes to multiple tumors of the nervous system. Most common are bilateral vestibular schwannomas; intracranial and spinal meningiomas, gliomas, neurofibromas, and posterior subcapsular lenticular opacities.

Vestibular schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from the intracanalicular segment of the inferior division of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle can lead to an "ice cream cone" appearance in MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with seborrheic dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has a well-established association with seborrheic dermatitis, with an incidence of up to 95% in HIV-infected patients.

This is due to a combination of factors, i.e. an impaired immune function, increased sebum production, and overgrowth of Malassezia. Other risk factors include Parkinson’s disease or central nervous system disorders. 

Seborrheic dermatitis is a skin condition caused by lipophilic yeasts from the Malassezia species. These yeasts are found in parts of the body with high oil production, such as the scalp, face, and body folds. Infection by Malassezia results in an abnormal shedding of keratinocytes, degradation of sebum, and disruption of the lipid balance on the skin surface. Treatment of adult seborrheic dermatitis is with topical antifungals (Ketoconzaole/Selenium sulfide), topical glucocorticoids, and in some cases topical calcineurin inhibitors. The image below shows seborrheic dermatitis on the face.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculosis (TB) of the skin can cause a variety of skin lesions, one of such being scrofuloderma. However, TB is not a common risk factor for seborrheic dermatitis. 

Option C: Dermatophytoses are fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails. Complications may occur due to bacterial superinfection. They are not a common risk factor for seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory immune-mediated disease of the skin and multiple other organ systems. It is generally characterized by papulosquamous skin lesions with silvery white scales showing isomorphic (Koebner’s) phenomena. Psoriasis is not a risk factor for seborrheic dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a sudden, severe, painless diminution of vision in his right eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect is present. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which of the following is not a treatment modality in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient developing sudden, severe painless diminution of vision, with relative afferent pupillary defect and fundoscopy of the eye showing massive retinal haemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance, are all suggestive of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Intravitreal mannitol is not a part of the treatment modality in CRVO. 

CRVO is further classified into two types:

  • Non-ischemic CRVO: occurs secondary to venous stasis. It is the most common type of CRVO of the two.
  • Ischemic CRVO: occurs due to acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is also termed hemorrhagic retinopathy. Ischemic CRVO presents with sudden loss of vision and Relative afferent pupil defect (RAPD).

Pathognomic features of ischemic CRVO that differentiate it from non-ischemic CRVO are:

  • RAPD
  • Reduced amplitude of B-wave on electroretinogram
  • Visual field defects

Complications of the disease:

  • Neovascular Glaucoma known as 100-day glaucoma
  • Neovascularization of iris known as Rubeosis iridis
  • Vitreous haemorrhage
  • Proliferative retinopathy

Other Options:

Treatment for non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion involves intravitreal triamcinolone, dexamethasone intravitreal implant, anti-VEGF drugs and pan-retinal photocoagulation. 

NOTE: Mannitol may be used as an occular hypotensive in patients with primary angle closure glaucome which is a risk factor for CRVO, but since this patient has painless loss of vision it is not likely in this case.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is undergoing a routine fundoscopy. Which of the following is the earliest finding likely to be found that would suggest a diagnosis of non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.solution:
Microaneurysms are the earliest finding in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) and is also very likely to be found in patients with a milder form of disease.

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR).
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).
  • Diabetic maculopathy.
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A neonate presents with cholestatic jaundice. On examination, the baby has a triangular face with a pointed chin and prominent ears. Auscultation reveals a harsh cardiac murmur. X-ray reveals butterfly vertebrae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with cholestatic jaundice, triangular facies with a pointed chin and prominent ears, a harsh cardiac murmur, and butterfly vertebra on X-ray is suggestive of Alagille syndrome.

Alagille syndrome (arteriohepatic dysplasia) is characterized by a marked reduction of the interlobular bile ducts in the portal triads. This usually presents as cholestatic jaundice with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in the neonatal period. Infants have associated dysmorphic facies. This includes a triangular face with a broad forehead, prominent ears, and a pointed chin due to an underdeveloped mandible. 

It is associated with congenital heart defects like peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis, pulmonary atresia, tetralogy of Fallot, or ventricular septal defects which can manifest as a harsh cardiac murmur. Associated vertebral anomalies include “butterfly” vertebrae, fusion of adjacent vertebrae, and spina bifida occulta. It can also be associated with eye defects. 

Investigations reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with a cholestatic pattern of liver function tests. A liver biopsy will reveal inflammation and paucity of interlobular bile ducts. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the human jagged 1 gene (JAG1) in a majority of the patients. 

Other options:

Option A: Noonan syndrome is characterized by facial dysmorphism (down-slanting palpebral fissure, low-set ears, hypertelorism), a webbed neck, skeletal anomalies (like scoliosis, pectus excavatum), and cardiac defects (most commonly pulmonary valve stenosis). It is not associated with cholestatic jaundice. 

Option C: Williams syndrome is characterized by elfin facies, cardiac defects (most commonly supravalvular aortic stenosis), hypotonia, and hypercalcemia. It is not associated with cholestatic jaundice or vertebral anomalies.

Option D: CHARGE syndrome is characterized by coloboma of the eye, heart defects, atresia choanae, retardation of growth, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities. It is not associated with cholestatic jaundice or vertebral anomalies.

questions.text: A newborn is being investigated for teratogenic drug exposure. A chest X-ray taken is shown below. Which of the following drugs was most likely consumed by the mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The above chest x-ray shows a “box-shaped heart sign” seen in Ebstein anomaly, which is strongly associated with in-utero exposure to lithium. 

Ebstein's anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This results in tricuspid regurgitation and leads to the enlargement of the right atrium producing the characteristic box-shaped heart. The right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow and there will be functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) resulting in cyanosis at birth.

Other options:

Option B: Valproate is associated with spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, and ventricular Septal Defect. 

Option C: Statins are associated with vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects.

Option D: Phenytoin is associated with Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta and Patent Ductus Arteriosus.

questions.text: Identify the suturing technique shown below:
questions.solution:
The illustration shows horizontal mattress suture. Below is an image showing the overhead view of a horizontal mattress suture with the dashed lines representing the parts under the skin.

Mattress sutures can either be vertical or horizontal. The initial suture is inserted as in an interrupted suture. The needle can then be moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound once again. In case of a horizontal mattress, the second bite is placed so that the suture is in the same horizontal plane as the first, and on the surface, the suture appears parallel to the wound; whereas in a vertical mattress (Option A), the second bite is placed so that the suture is in the same vertical plane as the first, and on the surface, the suture appears perpendicular to the wound. Below is an image of a vertical mattress suture.

Such sutures are very useful in producing an accurate approximation of irregular wound edges. They can produce either eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

Other options:

Option C: For a continuous or running suture, the first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Option D: A figure-of-eight suture is similar to a continuous suture with just two bites, where the exit strand from the second bite is knotted with the entry strand of the first bite. Below is an image of a figure of 8 suture.

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of the type of cartilage shown in the slide below?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts elastic cartilage, which is mostly found in the Epiglottis. The slide's blue-black tint is a result of dyeing the elastic fibres using Verhoeff's staining technique.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium.

On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

Elastic cartilage is found in:

  • External ear
  • External auditory meatus
  • Auditory tube
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Epiglottis
  • Apices of arytenoids

Other options:

Option A and D: Thyroid cartilage and the costal cartilage of ribs are examples of hyaline cartilage.

 

Option B: The pubic symphysis is an example of fibrocartilage.

questions.text: You are studying the visual pigment cycle in the physiology lab. Identify the substance that converts cis-retinal to trans-retinal.
questions.solution:
The substance that converts cis-retinal to trans-retinal is rhodopsin.

Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in the outer segment of rods responsible for scotopic vision (night/ dark vision). It is a light-sensitive pigment and consists of opsin and 11-cis retinal.

When light is absorbed by rhodopsin, it decomposes very quickly. This leads to an instantaneous change of the cis form of retinal into an all-trans form. This all-trans-retinal separates from scotopsin to produce bathorhodopsin. Bathorhodopsin is very unstable and decays to form lumirhodopsin, which then decays and forms metarhodopsin I, metarhodopsin II, and finally, into the completely split products scotopsin and all-trans-retinal. 

Metarhodopsin II is also called activated rhodopsin, and it produces excitatory changes in the rods, which transmits optic nerve action potentials. to the central nervous system.

Re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal back into 11-cis retinal. This requires metabolic energy and is catalyzed by retinal isomerase. 11-cis retinal then recombines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin. Rhodopsin now remains stable until it is triggered by light energy to start decomposing again.

Role of vitamin A: The second route of re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal into all-trans-retinol, which is a form of vitamin A. All-trans-retinol is converted into 11- cis retinol by isomerase. 11-cis retinol is then converted into 11-cis retinal, combines with scotopsin, and forms new rhodopsin.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the colon. While explaining the pathogenesis of the disease to him, which of the following would you mention as the "first hit" in the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence?

LOH - Loss of heterozygosity
questions.solution:
The mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21 is the "first hit" in the classical adenoma-carcinoma sequence. 

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI)
  3. CpG island methylator phenotype pathway.
Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway, accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. Both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities and inactivation of the normal β-catenin. The loss of the second APC allele follows the "second hit." Mutations of KRAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are also involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency, leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX which may enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - In these tumors, the MLH1 promoter region is typically hypermethylated, thus reducing MLH1 expression and repair function. Activating mutations in the oncogene BRAF are common in these cancers. KRAS and TP53 are not typically mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, is the signature of this pathway of carcinogenesis.

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is found to have jaundice and elevated direct bilirubin levels, two days after undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following classification systems is used for the most likely complication that has occurred?
questions.solution:
Development of jaundice with elevated bilirubin levels following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy should raise a suspicion of bile duct injury, for which the Strasberg classification system is used. 

The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for complete morphological evaluation of the biliary tree. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. HIDA scan can be used for confirming the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. 

Below is an image depicting the Strasberg classification.

Other options:

Option A: Todani classification is used to classify choledochal cysts.

Option C: Perihilar Cholangiocarcinomas, also called Klatskin Tumors, are cholangiocarcinomas at the confluence of the hepatic ducts, which is the most common site, and they classified based on the Bismuth-Corlette Classification system.

Option D: Kasai classification is used to classify the types of biliary atresia.

questions.text:
A child presents with scattered petechiae and bruising. There is no history of epistaxis or any other signs of bleeding. Evaluation reveals a platelet count of 50,000/µL. A diagnosis of ITP is made. What is the most appropriate management for this child?

ITP: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of scattered petechiae, bruising, and no other signs of bleeding suggest mild ITP. Observation is the most appropriate management for this child.

ITP is the most common cause of acute thrombocytopenia in children. It usually follows a viral illness. Children usually present with generalized petechiae and purpura. It may be associated with symptoms of mucocutaneous bleeding (like epistaxis, and gum bleeding). Laboratory investigations will reveal thrombocytopenia with a normal platelet morphology.

The management depends on bleeding manifestations and platelet count. No therapy is required for patients with mild (bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis) to moderate (more severe skin and mucosal lesions) symptoms and a platelet count above 20,000/µL. Close observation is recommended for such children.

For children with severe symptoms like prolonged mucocutaneous bleeding, treatment with either intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) or corticosteroids is recommended (option C). IVIG produces rapid response in most cases. A short course of oral corticosteroids has also been effective in raising platelet count above 20,000/µL and minimizing symptoms.

Platelet transfusions (option B) are usually avoided in ITP unless there is life-threatening bleeding like an intracranial hemorrhage. Splenectomy (option D) is reserved for children above 4 years of age with severe symptoms that have lasted over a year (chronic ITP) or for life-threatening hemorrhage in acute ITP which is resistant to other treatments.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is performing a clinical test wherein he applies pressure over the lacrimal sac and observes mucopurulent discharge from the lower punctum. Which condition might this be diagnostic for?
questions.solution:
The test described above is the regurgitation test, wherein applying pressure over the lacrimal sac causes regurgitation of mucopurulent discharge from the lower punctum and is used for the diagnosis of chronic dacryocystitis.

Chronic dacryocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It can occur in congenital dacrocystitis which occurs because of the stasis of secretions due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. Incomplete canalization of the valve of Hasner is the most common cause.

Patients with congenital dacrocystitis present with epiphora (watery eyes) during the first week of life, followed by mucopurulent discharge, which may be elicited by performing the regurgitation test as described above.

The treatment plan is decided according to the age at which the baby is brought. Massaging over the lacrimal sac and topical antibiotics are used as the mainstay of treatment. Probing of the nasolacrimal duct with Bowman's probe is done if it persists even at 6 months of age. Other options include balloon catheter dilatation or intubation with a silicone tube where the tube is kept in the nasolacrimal duct for six months. Dacryocystorhinostomy is preferred after 4 years of age. 

Other options:

Option A: Stye, refers to external hordeolum, which is an acute suppurative inflammation of the eyelash follicles and the associated glands, hence, no discharge will be seen arising from the lacrimal sac.

Option C: Regurgitation test may be positive in chronic dacryocystitis during the stage of lacrimal mucocele, but is not seen in acute dacryocystitis.

Option D: Acute dacryoadenitis, which is the inflammation of the lacrimal gland (vs sac) is typically associated with painful swelling of the lateral part of the upper lid, leading to an S-shaped swelling. Painful proptosis may also be observed.

questions.text: All of the following factors trigger sickling in sickle cell disease, except
questions.solution:
All of the mentioned factors trigger sickling in sickle cell disease, except alkalosis. 

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This results in the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS). 

The major pathophysiology involves chronic hemolysis and microvascular occlusion. Hypoxia (option D) increases the concentration of deoxygenated HbS promoting RBC sickling. These sickle cells can disrupt circulation causing vascular occlusion and tissue infarction. Vaso-occlusive crises, also known as pain crises, are a result of this hypoxic injury and infarction. These crises predominantly affect the bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, and penis.

Several factors can trigger the sickling of RBCs. Dehydration (option A) can increase the mean cell hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) which results in polymerization of HbS. A decrease in blood pH i.e. acidosis, increases the fraction of deoxygenated HbS and can trigger sickling. Infection (option C) or states of inflammation can increase the expression of adhesion molecules and enhance the tendency of sickling.

questions.text:
A young man with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. A bolus of both normal saline and IV short-acting insulin is administered. What is the next step in management?

Random blood sugar: 500mg/dl
Urine ketones ++
Serum potassium - 5.4mEq/L

choices.text: Start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion
Administer bicarbonate 50 mEq in sterile water
Start continuous insulin infusion and administer potassium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The next step in management is to start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion.

DKA is a complication of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus common in type 1 diabetes mellitus but can also occur in type 2. It occurs in the setting of absolute or relative insulin deficiency along with glucagon excess leading to extreme hyperglycemia.

Clinical features include severe nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and severe volume depletion. Signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor on the patient’s breath, tachycardia, dehydration, and hypotension. 

The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL
  • Ketosis or ketones in the urine
  • Metabolic acidosis with pH <7.4 and HCO3 <15 mEq/L
  • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis

Pseudohyponatremia (dilutional) is seen as a result of hyperglycemia due to osmotic shift. Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Potassium levels at presentation may be normal or elevated despite total body deficit, due to intracellular shift. If the initial serum potassium <3.3 mEq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia. This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia.

The mainstay management of diabetic ketoacidosis includes urgent fluid resuscitation and maintenance, along with insulin therapy, electrolyte replacement, and supportive care. The algorithm of management is given below. 

Criteria for resolution of ketoacidosis include:
  • Blood glucose <200 mg/dL, and
  • Two of the following criteria:
    • Serum bicarbonate level ≥15 mEq/L
    • Venous pH >7.3
    • Anion gap ≤12 mEq/L

questions.text: Following a reported snake bite, a patient shows up at the emergency department. Despite receiving medical treatment, the patient died. The patient's relatives bring a snake that they believe caused the bite, as seen in the picture. What is the probable cause of the patient's death?
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic. The probable cause of the patient's demise is respiratory paralysis.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia are the first signs of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases, the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

Other Options:

Option B and C: Venom from the Viperidae family of snakes (Pit Viper, Saw-scaled Viper) is vasculotoxic. Presentation can be as coagulopathy and hypovolemic shock due to widespread bleeding. 

Option D: Sea snake venom is myotoxic. The main presentation is generalized rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: The histopathological analysis of a myocardial biopsy taken from a patient with acute rheumatic carditis is shown below. What type of necrosis is associated with the finding seen in the below image?
questions.solution:
The most likely lesion shown in the myocardial biopsy specimen of acute rheumatic carditis is Aschoff's bodies, which shows fibrinoid necrosis.

Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

The Aschoff bodies consist of a focus of fibrinoid necrosis of collagen fibers, leukocyte infiltrates, and occasional large histiocytes called Anitschkow cells. The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and large, vesicular nuclei, as seen in the image below.


Other options :

Option A - Coagulative necrosis is a form of necrosis in which the architecture of the dead tissue is preserved for some days. it has a firm texture. The injury denatures the structural proteins and enzymes so the dead cell proteolysis is blocked. The necrotic cells are broken down by the action of lysosomal enzymes derived from infiltrating leukocytes, and they also remove debris from the dead cells by phagocytosis. 

The image below shows the coagulative necrosis of cardiomyocytes.


Option C- Fat necrosis is a focal area of fat destruction, due to the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substances of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. It is mainly seen in acute pancreatitis. 

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within the breast tissue.


Option D- Caseous necrosis is often seen in foci of tuberculosis infection. On microscopy, these necrotic areas appear as a structureless collection of fragmented or lysed cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border. This appears as a characteristic focus of inflammation called a granuloma.

The image below shows tuberculoid granuloma associated with caseous necrosis (upper right) and surrounding epithelioid cells, Langhans' multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman is on anti-arrhythmic drugs after she had ventricular fibrillation 3 months back. During her routine diabetic checkup, the ophthalmological examination shows corneal findings as in the image. This is due to the use of ____________
questions.solution:
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines, as shown in the above image, is called corneal verticillata. Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of amiodarone.

Other causes of corneal verticillata: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic used in the management of resistant VT and recurrent VF and is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed. It causes rapid termination of such arrhythmias when administered IV. Adverse effects include pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, thyroid disorders, photodermatitis, and corneal deposits. 

Adverse effects of amiodarone:

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on IV injection and after drug cumulation
  • Photosensitization
  • Corneal microdeposits -corneal verticillata
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Goitre, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism

questions.text: An abdominal X-ray of a baby who presented with abdominal distension and hematochezia showed air in the bowel wall. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC.

NEC is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in newborns. It is characterized by mucosal or transmural inflammation resulting in necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. Three major risk factors implicated are prematurity (the greatest risk factor), formula feeding, and bacterial colonization of the intestine.

Babies usually present within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal vein gas, and pneumoperitoneum (indicates perforation).

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows).


Management of NEC includes supportive measures like keeping the baby nil per oral (NPO), nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk.

questions.text: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is caused by excessive activation of which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Atypical or familial HUS is an inherited cause of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia associated with thrombocytopenia and renal failure. It is caused by defects in complement factor H, membrane cofactor protein, or factor I. All these factors serve as complement regulators. Deficiency of these causes impaired control and excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Typical HUS occurs in children following a gastrointestinal infection caused by Shiga toxin-producing strains like E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae. It is characterized by widespread injury to small vessel endothelium, leading to thrombotic microangiopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complete fracture?
questions.solution:
Torus fracture is a type of incomplete fracture.

A torus fracture, also known as Buckle fracture, is an incomplete fracture characterized by a visible deformity or buckling of the bone on a radiograph without complete separation. It is commonly observed in pediatric patients, particularly in the distal radius of the forearm, resulting from compressive forces. 

The fractured bone typically appears raised or bulging on one side while remaining intact on the other. Due to its stable nature, a torus fracture often requires minimal intervention, such as immobilization with a splint or cast, and tends to heal rapidly without significant complications.

Other options:

Option A: Segmental fracture is a type of fracture where the bone breaks into two or more separate parts. Below is a radiograph showing segmental injury of the ulna associated with a single diaphyseal fracture of the radius

 Option B: Spiral fracture is a type of complete fracture where the bone has been twisted apart. Below is a radiograph showing a proximal third diaphyseal fracture of the femur.

Option D: Chance fracture is a type of complete fracture where there is splitting of the vertebral body, the spinous process and neural arch. Below is a CT showing a chance fracture of the L1 vertebra.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

questions.text: In an asthma patient, drug zafirlukast relieves asthmatic symptoms by acting as a __________
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. They are competitive antagonists of the cysLT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

Option A: Omalizumab is an Anti-IgE receptor used in asthma.
