questions.text: As a first year resident you are asked to use the Gridiron incision to perform an open appendectomy. Which of the following incisions will you use?
questions.solution:
The labelled incision '3' is the McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy. Below is the image of various other abdominal incisions.

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favoured in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and the adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique mus-cle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A patient with polyhydramnios has a spontaneous rupture of membranes. On examination, the umbilical cord is felt through the cervix. Which of the following patterns is the most likely to be seen on fetal heart rate monitoring?
questions.solution:
Cord prolapse must be suspected when variable decelerations and bradycardia are detected on a continuous fetal heart rate monitor. 

Variable deceleration is associated with umbilical cord compression in cases of prolapse and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end of the deceleration. These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration.

Footling breech has the highest chances of cord prolapse among the four types of breech presentation. Overall, the highest chances of cord prolapse are in a transverse lie. Amniotomies are also a risk factor for the development of cord prolapses. 

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors: 

  • if the baby is living or dead,
  • the maturity of the baby, and
  • the degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

If the baby is dead, it should be reconfirmed with ultrasound and spontaneous delivery can be allowed when death is confirmed. Destructive operations are rarely needed. Immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 

  • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time
  • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
  • Transverse lie - internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible, relieve pressure on the cord, stop oxytocin infusion, and give oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids.

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

Other options:

Option A: In early decelerations the onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It suggests fetal head compression resulting in vagal nerve activation.

Option C: In late decelerations the fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Option D:  Sinusoidal pattern has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting > 20 min, thus resembling a sine wave. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal hypoxia (acidosis). It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother.

questions.text: Chest injuries cause conditions that are classified as immediately life-threatening and potentially life-threatening. Which of the following is considered a potentially life threatening chest injury?
questions.solution:
Trauma to the chest can lead to conditions that are classified into 6 immediately life-threatening and 6 potentially life-threatening conditions, together known as the ‘deadly dozen’.

 Immediately Life Threatening Potentially Life Threatening
Airway obstruction Aortic injuries
Tension pneumothorax Tracheobronchial injuries
Pericardial tamponade Myocardial contusion
Open pneumothorax Diaphragmatic rupture
Massive hemothorax Esophageal injury
Flail Chest Pulmonary contusion

The immediately life-threatening conditions should be diagnosed and managed during the primary survey and potentially life-threatening conditions should be diagnosed and managed during the secondary survey. 

ATLS 10th edition classifies flail chest as a potentially life-threatening incident, whereas Bailey 28th Edition classifies it as an immediate life-threatening event. It is recommended that the user look into alternative options prior to selecting the most optimal response.

Related Pearl: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels
  • Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.
  • (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: The active principle of the toxin extracted from the poisonous plant shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows a spherical fruit with sharp spines, characteristic of the Datura plant. The active ingredients include the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. 

Datura poisoning:

The common names include thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet. The active ingredients include the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. The seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. 

Toxic manifestations of Datura:

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises up to 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

Treatment

  • Gastric lavage or decontamination with activated charcoal or tannic acid: Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus, gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.
  • Physostigmine in severe toxicity given 1-2 mg IM/IV after every half hour as required: It is a physiological antidote. Pilocarpine may also be given.

Medico-legal importance:

In India, Datura is used as a stupefying poison prior to robbery, kidnapping, and rape. It is also known as a rail-road poison, as it is commonly encountered during a journey. Robbers disguised as saints may offer ‘prasad’ mixed with Datura seeds and rob the passengers.

Other options:

Option A: Thevatoxin is the active principle of yellow oleander.

Option C: Tetrahydro-cannabinol is the active principle of cannabis.

Option D: The poisonous component of Ricinus communis is toxalbumin ricin. It is a glycoprotein that blocks protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following apoproteins is an activator of lipoprotein lipase?
questions.solution:
Apo C-II is an activator of lipoprotein lipase. 

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyses the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Apolipoproteins or apoproteins are the protein moiety of lipoproteins. Usually one or more of these are present in each lipoprotein. They are denoted as apo followed by the letters A, B, C, etc. The various functions of apolipoproteins include: 

  • They are part of the structure of lipoproteins
  • They can act as enzyme co-factors, for example, apo A-I for lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), apo C-II for lipoprotein lipase
  • They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B100 for LDL receptors

Other options: 

Option A: Apo A is the major apolipoprotein of HDL (high-density lipoprotein).

Option B: Apo B100 is the major apolipoprotein of LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). Apo B48 is the major apolipoprotein of chylomicrons.

Option D: Apo E is transferred by HDL to nascent chylomicrons and nascent VLDL to form mature forms of those particles.

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea, and fatigue 12 months post childbirth. She has dry skin and hair and decreased libido. Her MRI is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea and fatigue 12 months after childbirth with MRI showing pituitary necrosis, likely has Sheehan syndrome (Ischemic pituitary necrosis). The most appropriate treatment for this patient is hormone replacement therapy; 

The goal of management in Sheehan syndrome is to replace the deficient pituitary hormones. This is typically done with a combination of hydrocortisone, levothyroxine, and oxytocin. Sheehan syndrome is due to pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss after child birth.

The pituitary undergoes hyperplastic enlargement during pregnancy, which increases the risk of haemorrhage and infarction.

The most prominent symptoms are the inability to nurse (lactational failure) due to absent prolactin secretion and postpartum amenorrhea due to absent FSH and LH secretion.

Patients affected may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoglycemia due to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, and hyponatremia. Aldosterone is unaffected, and there is no salt wasting. Adrenal insufficiency is the most life-threatening complication. Hence, the first hormone to be replaced is glucocorticoids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

Option C: Bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor analogue used for the management of lactorrhea seen in a functional prolactinoma. 

Option D: Pituitary resection is appropriate for craniopharyngiomas, benign tumours derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). Patients present with features of raised intracranial pressure, visual impairment in the form of bitemporal hemianopia and endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, diabetes insipidus, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypo-function. MRI shows calcified cystic masses in the supra-sellar region.

questions.text:
Which among the following incisions is made during LSCS?

LSCS- Lower segment Cesarean section
questions.solution:
Pfannenstiel incision, represented by 4 in the image above is the most common incision made in lower section caesarean delivery.

It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curbvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The various incisions mentioned in the image are:

Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.

Incision '2' - The Maylard incision is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.

Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend who says that a popular actor is in love with her and stalks her. The woman’s friend refutes her claims. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erotomania is a delusional disorder where the patient believes someone is in love with him/her, against evidence to the contrary. It is also known as De Clérambault syndrome.

The lover in the delusion is often a person of higher social status. It is more common in women.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Anxious parents brought their infant to the pediatric outpatient with complaints of an abnormal increase in the size of his head. Investigations revealed hydrocephalus due to the vein of Galen malformation. Identify the great vein of Galen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The great vein of Galen is marked as '1' in the image given above.

The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus, located along the junction between the falx and the tentorium cerebelli.

Clinical significance:

  • Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM) is the most common form of symptomatic cerebrovascular malformation in neonates and infants.
  • Vein of Galen malformation can result in hydrocephalus, heart failure, or rarely, hemorrhage.
  • There may be the absence of great vein of Galen in some congenital disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the lab criteria for diagnosis of APLA syndrome?
questions.solution:
Raised aPTT is not a lab criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before 10 weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), also referred to as a recurrent miscarriage or habitual abortion, is historically defined as 3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks from the last menstrual period. 

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text:
A child is admitted with a high fever and bloody mucoid diarrhea. Stool cultures reveal oxidase-negative, gram-negative bacillus. Following enrichment in selenite F broth, it is cultured on XLD agar as shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?

XLD: xylose lysine deoxycholate
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child and the image showing red-coloured colonies without a black centre on XLD agar are suggestive of bacillary dysentery caused by Shigella.

Shigella causes bacillary dysentery by producing an exotoxin known as Shiga toxin or verotoxin. It invades the M cells (specialised epithelial cells of the gut) to cause inflammatory diarrhoea. It presents with frequent passage of loose, scanty faeces containing blood and mucus, along with abdominal cramps, tenesmus, fever and vomiting. Hemolytic uremic syndrome can occur as a complication in severe cases.

Shigellae are short, gram-negative rods that are non-motile, non-sporing, and non-capsulated. They are indole positive, urea and oxidase negative, and ferment glucose. Colonies on MacConkey agar are colourless due to the absence of lactose fermentation. Hektoen enteric (HE) agar, xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar (XLD), and deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) are the selective mediums used for subculture.

XLD agar is a selective growth medium used to isolate Salmonella and Shigella species from other enteric pathogens. It has a bright red colour due to the indicator phenol red. Sugar fermentation lowers the pH, and the phenol red indicator turns yellow. Shigella colonies cannot ferment the sugar to produce xylose and therefore remain red.

Other options: 

Option A: Salmonella metabolises thiosulfate to produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which leads to the formation of red-coloured colonies with black centres on XLD agar and allows them to be differentiated from the Shigella colonies.

Option C: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative lactose fermenting bacteria and does not grow on XLD agar.

Option D: Enterococcus is a gram-positive bacteria and produces tiny magenta-pink colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a patient in the early stages of retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, impaired central vision is least likely to be seen in patients with retinitis pigmentosa. Even patients with advanced disease often have a small island of residual central vision, demonstrable by perimetry. Only in very advanced cases, central vision impairment is seen.

Nyctalopia/ impaired dark adaptation is often the presenting symptom in retinitis pigmentosa. Also, contrast sensitivity is often affected at an earlier stage, usually earlier than visual acuity.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Occular examination will reveal normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision may be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy will show bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There will be severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataract, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer-controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Cancer cells often have reduced expression of class I MHC antigens. Which of the following cells of the immune system can exploit this property to kill cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells can exploit the property that cancer cells have reduced amounts of surface proteins like class I MHC antigen to kill them. The cytotoxicity of NK cells is not antibody dependent or MHC restricted.

Natural killer cells (NK cells) are also known as large granular lymphocytes. They are essential cells of innate immunity. They act against malignant and virus-infected cells. NK cells are identified by CD16, CD56, and CD94 cell surface receptors. 

NK cells' activity is augmented by interferons and upon activation, they bind to glycoprotein receptors on the surface of target cells and release perforins. Perforins create pores in the membrane of the target cells. Through these pores, cytotoxic factors like tumor necrosis factor-beta (TNF-β) enter the cells and destroy them by apoptosis.

A subset of large-granular lymphocytes are called Antibody dependent cytotoxic cells (ADCC). These cells have the capability of killing target cells that are coated by IgG antibodies. These cells were formerly called killer cells, but are now classified under NK cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of amenorrhea 3 months after an abortion. A hysteroscopy reveals intrauterine adhesions. What is most likely to be seen with regard to FSH levels and progesterone challenge in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of amenorrhea after an abortion (likely a dilatation and curettage) with intrauterine adhesions has most likely developed Asherman’s syndrome. FSH levels are normal and no withdrawal bleeding occurs to progesterone challenge in patients with Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. This leads to amenorrhea despite normal FSH levels and lack of withdrawal bleeding to progesterone challenge. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion. 

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) shows contrast dye filling an irregulary-shaped endometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance.

Saline infusion sonography can be performed as an alternative to HSG. Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statement about the contrast agent iohexol.

CT - computed tomography

choices.text: It is an intravascular contrast medium for radiography, including CT
It is an iodinated non-ionic contrast medium
It has a high osmolarity, which increases the risk of contrast nephropathy
It is preferred for the diagnostic work-up of esophageal perforation

questions.solution:
Iohexol is a commonly used iodine-based, low-osmolar, non-ionic contrast media. It is preferred to use in patients with deranged renal function as it has a low risk of contrast nephropathy. Therefore, the statement C is incorrect.

Iodinated, water-soluble contrast media are commonly used as an intravascular contrast medium for radiographic imaging, including angiography and computed tomography (CT) (Statement A). The iodine provides radiopacity. Low-osmolar and non-ionic media have taken over from other iodinated compounds as they are more stable, more soluble, and less toxic.

Iohexol, because of the above properties, produces fewer abnormalities in the renal blood flow, therefore causing less endothelial damage. It is the preferred contrast media for the diagnostic work-up of oesophagal perforation to obtain fluoroscopic images (Statement D) as it is associated with a lower risk of pulmonary edema which can occur following the aspiration of high-osmolar agents such as gastrografin.

questions.text: You notice the following equipment in the principal biomedical waste handling facility. This equipment is used for the treatment of all the following, except ____

choices.text: Waste sharps such as needles and syringes

questions.solution:
The given image shows an incinerator. Incineration is used for the treatment of all the listed wastes, except waste sharps such as needles and syringes.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 

Waste sharps such as needles and syringes are sterilized by autoclaving, followed by shredding, mutilation, or encapsulation in a metal container or cement concrete. They are then sent for final disposal to iron foundries.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants. questions.text: The government of India starts a new initiative where rehabilitation centers are opened across the country to support wounded army soldiers with medical and psychological aid. Which level of prevention does this initiative fall under?
questions.solution:
The rehabilitation of wounded soldiers with medical and psychological aid falls under the tertiary level of prevention.

The tertiary level of prevention signifies intervention in the late pathogenesis phase. Tertiary prevention can be defined as "all measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health, and promote the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions."

Other levels of prevention are:

Primordial prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared. This is employed for health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to the mode of lifestyle like smoking, unhealthy eating patterns, and sedentary life. These patterns are discouraged from early childhood. The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

Primary prevention is defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''. It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem and is accomplished by measures promoting general health and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. Examples include immunization, sanitation, and the protection of food. They include two strategies :

  • Population (mass) strategy: where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Secondary prevention is defined as the "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications."The specific interventions are early diagnostic tests like screening tests and adequate treatment. The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process, and it is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.

questions.text: A woman with gallstones presents with abdominal pain. On ultrasonography, the stone is found to be in the duct that opens into the ampulla of Vater. Identify the correct statement regarding the location of this duct.

choices.text: Anterior to the head of the pancreas
Posterior to the head of the pancreas
Anterior to the neck of the pancreas
Posterior to the neck of the pancreas

questions.solution:
The duct that opens into the ampulla of Vater is the common bile duct (CBD). It is situated posterior to the pancreatic head.

The common bile duct is formed by the union of the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct near the porta hepatis.

 

The CBD has the following four parts:     

  • Supraduodenal part: in the free margin of the lesser omentum.
  • Retroduodenal part: behind the first part of the duodenum
  • Infraduodenal part: behind/embedded within the head of the pancreas
  • Intraduodenal part: unites with the major pancreatic duct within the wall of the second part of the duodenum to form the hepatopancreatic ampulla or the ampulla of Vater. The ampulla opens into the major duodenal papilla.

Other options:

Option A: The first part of the duodenum, transverse colon, and jejunum are situated anterior to the head of the pancreas.

Option C: The pylorus of the stomach and the peritoneum covering the posterior wall of the lesser sac are situated anterior to the neck of the pancreas.

Option D: The formation of the portal vein is located posterior to the neck of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins acts by increasing cyclic AMP levels?
questions.solution:
The pertussis toxin produced by Bordetella pertussis acts by increasing cyclic AMP levels.

The pertussis toxin is an exotoxin with subunits AB. Subunit A carries the biologic activity and subunit B that binds the complex to the cell membrane. The A subunit acts by ADP-ribosylation of the α subunit of Gi protein. G proteins can be either stimulatory (Gs) or inhibitory (Gi) for the production of the 2nd messenger cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. Inhibition of Gi protein by the toxin increases cAMP levels causing impaired cellular signalling. This results in lymphocytosis, hypoglycemia, and impaired host immune response. 

Other virulence factors include the tracheal cytotoxin causing impaired ciliary activity of respiratory epithelium and inflammation, a heat-labile toxin, and filamentous hemagglutinin which promotes adherence to the cilia.

Bordetella pertussis causes whooping cough. The disease is characterized by the following phases:

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks with symptoms of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks. Causes worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout
  • Convalescent - Lasts for weeks to months with progressive reduction of symptoms

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be made by isolation of the causative organism from a nasopharyngeal swab, followed by cultivation on Bordet-Gengou medium.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes for pre-conceptional counselling following a spontaneous abortion at 20 weeks. Which of the following instruments will you use to investigate cervical insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Hegar’s dilator can be used in the interconceptional period in investigating the presence of cervical insufficiency. Passage of the dilator beyond the internal os without any resistance or pain and the absence of snap on its withdrawal indicates incompetence.

The image shows various instruments such as:

  1. Sims uterine curette - a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.
  2. Hegar dilator (numbers 6-8) - a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
  3. Sims uterine sound - to measure the uterocervical length.
  4. Karman's cannula - used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula - used in hysterosalpingography.
  6. Rubin's cannula - used in hysterosalpingography.

Cervical incompetence is characterized by painless cervical dilation in the absence of uterine contraction, usually diagnosed in the second trimester. Cervical length <25 mm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm on sonography is suggestive of cervical insufficiency. On speculum examination, there is painless cervical shortening and dilatation. 

The risk factors include congenital uterine anomalies, multiple gestations, prior preterm birth, and iatrogenic factors such as dilatation and curettage, vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix and amputation of the cervix. Diagnosis of the condition can be done in the interconceptional period in order to advise the mother regarding the potential need for cerclage placement.

questions.text: Examination of a 9-year-old patient reveals signs that are suggestive of potential abuse. A sample from the child's perianal region was obtained and was tested using potassium iodide. This resulted in the formation of dark brown needle-shaped rhombic crystals. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test performed in this scenario is the Florence test, which is utilized to identify the presence of seminal fluid in suspected cases of sexual abuse.

Florence test detects choline which is secreted by seminal vesicles. The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen.

Other options:

Option A: Barberio test is used to detect the presence of seminal fluid. The stain used is saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. If semen is present, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option C: Paraffin test is used to detect gunpowder residue (nitrate and nitrites). 

Option D: Kastle Meyer test is used to detect the presence of bloodstain. A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain.
This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test.

questions.text: A clinical trial is being done for a new drug for the treatment of migraine. The p-value was found to be 0.02. Which of the following is a correct statement?

choices.text: Trial is statistically insignificant and the null hypothesis is true
Trial is statistically insignificant but the null hypothesis is false
Trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is false
Trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is true

questions.solution:
The correct statement is the trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is false. 

In the given scenario, the p-value is 0.02 which is <0.05. This means that the possibility of an association between the new drug and pain relief purely by chance is only 2%. Hence, the null hypothesis is rejected. 

The possibility of pain relief due to the new drug is 98%. This is the alternate hypothesis.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of the 4th arch, except ______.
questions.solution:
Superior parathyroids and not inferior parathyroids, are derived from the 4th arch. Inferior parathyroids are derived from the 3rd arch.

Each pharyngeal arch is characterized by its own muscular components. The muscular components of each arch have their own cranial nerve. Wherever the muscle cells migrate, they carry their nerve component with them. The neurons of the 5th, 7th, 9th, and 10th cranial sensory ganglia that supply the pharyngeal arch structures are derived from ectodermal placodes (epipharyngeal placodes) and from the neural crest cells.

questions.text: All of the following structures are removed in Patey’s operation except?

choices.text: Large portion of skin, the centre of which overlies the tumour but which always includes the nipple
All of the fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla

questions.solution:
Patey's modification of modified radical mastectomy and does not involve the removal of the axillary vein.  

Patey's modified radical mastectomy is a total mastectomy. It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes up to level III along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss). The incision used is an elliptical Stewart incision. 

Other eponymous modifications of mastectomy:

  • Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy is a modification of Patey's procedure in which pectoralis minor is incised and not removed following which the level III nodes are approached.
  • Halsted radical mastectomy involves excision of the breast tissue, skin, and nipple-areolar complex, dissection of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles. 
  • In Auchincloss modified radical mastectomy, pectoralis minor is left intact and level III nodes are not removed.

questions.text: An elderly lady complains of recurrent right-sided headaches, nonspecific shoulder pain, and jaw pain on chewing for 6 months. ESR is 107mm/hr. Which of the following features would be characteristically seen in a biopsy specimen obtained from her?

choices.text: Multinucleated cells in the arterial intima and media
Eosinophils and neutrophils in the arterial intima and media
Lymphocytes and plasma cells in the arterial adventitia
Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent headaches, jaw claudication and non specific shoulder pain (likely polymyalgia rheumatica) with an elevated ESR most likely has giant cell arteritis. The presence of multinucleated cells, or giant cells in the arterial intima and media is the most suggestive biopsy feature of Giant cell arteritis (GCA). 

GCA is a chronic, large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the temporal arteries, but can also involve the aorta, its branches, and the ophthalmic arteries. It is the most common vasculitis in adults over 50 years.

Histopathology also shows panarteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation. Intimal thickening and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina are also seen (black arrow). Multinucleated giant cells are large cells with multiple nuclei that are formed by the fusion of macrophages (yellow arrow). They are a hallmark of GCA and are not typically seen in other types of vasculitis.

There is thickening and narrowing of the artery, resulting in thrombosis, ischemia or aneurysms. Symptoms include headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, fever, fatigue, and weight loss. It is also associated with mononeuritis multiplex; peripheral neuropathy in two or more separate nerve areas. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. 

Elevated ESR and anaemia are characteristic laboratory findings. Raised liver enzymes, especially alkaline phosphatase are common. Levels of IgG and complement may be raised. GCA is treated with corticosteroids.

Other options:

Option B: Eosinophils and neutrophils can be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome and Polyarteritis Nodosa. 

Option C: Lymphocytes and plasma cells are seen in many types of inflammation, including GCA, but are not specific.

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall can be seen in GCA, but is also seen in Polyarteritis Nodosa.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: Exclamation mark hair is seen in patients with which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
Exclamation mark hair is a feature of alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, it may progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are narrower at the base and therefore are called exclamation marks. The disease affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. Fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia is also seen in this condition.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T-lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required. Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows exclamation mark hair.

 

Other options - 

Option A: Telogen effluvium can occur 2-3 months after systemic stress such as surgery or illness, but it causes diffuse hair loss.

The image below shows a patient with telogen effluvium.

 

Option B: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows tinea capitis.

 

Option D: Trichotillomania is a behavioural disorder characterised by compulsive pulling of hair. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal. Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region. Dermoscopy of the scalp helps in differentiating it from alopecia areata - follicular orifices appear as yellow dots in trichotillomania. Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular haemorrhages. The presence of numerous empty canals is the most consistent feature of this condition.

The image below shows a patient with trichotillomania.

questions.text: Tizanidine is a drug used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Tizanidine is a α2 adrenergic receptor agonist.

Tizanidine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is used to treat spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or after stroke. Treatment is started with a low dose and gradually tilted upwards. Side effects include dry mouth, drowsiness, insomnia, and hallucinations.

Other options:

Option A: Nm receptor antagonism is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants. The drugs in this class include pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium, mivacurium, etc.

Option C: D2 receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine. It is used for the treatment of prolactinoma and Parkinson's disease.

Option D: GABA B receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of baclofen. It is used for the same purpose as tizanidine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug acts by inhibiting arabinosyl transferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol inhibits the arabinosyl transferase III enzyme, thereby disrupting the arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This in turn disrupts the assembly of mycobacterial cell wall.

Option A: Ethionamide inhibits activity of the InhA gene product, resulting in inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis.

Option C: Pyrazinamide inhibits fatty acid synthase-I leading to inhibition of cell membrane synthesis.

Option D: Kanamycin is an antitubercular aminoglycoside that binds to the 30S subunit and thus inhibits mycobacterial protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
questions.solution:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement.

This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation. 

The features of P mitrale are:

  • lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves
  • Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA)

P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. 

Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6.

Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below show the transverse section of the uterus and the histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Patients present with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. Diagnosis is usually made with transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) or MR imaging. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: At the time of the victim's autopsy, the wound on the forehead was noted to have a  patterned abrasion and a stellate laceration. No blackening or grease collar is present. What is the possible range from which the gun inflicted injury?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, patterned abrasion (muzzle imprint) and a stellate laceration on the wound, suggests a contact shot entry wound. A contact shot entry wound on the skull typically has a stellate shape due to high-energy impact. 

The main objective of the study of a firearm wound (Ballistics) is to establish the range and direction of firing, the ultimate purpose is to determine the weapon used for firing. Firearm wounds are fundamentally of two main types: wounds of entry and wounds of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.

To determine the range of firing, the following parameters are used:

  • The entry wound size and shape
  • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
  • Blackening, Tattooing, Singeing of hair, Abrasion collar, and Grease collar
  • Hair should be preserved to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonization/desiccation in close range, also from lead deposition around the wound to assess the range of firing.

questions.text: A woman has a spontaneous abortion at 20 weeks of gestation. Under the Employees State Insurance (ESI) Act, what is the duration of maternity benefit she will receive following the abortion?
questions.solution:
According to the ESI Act, women can avail of 6 weeks of maternity benefits if they suffer a miscarriage or an abortion.

The Employees State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948 (revised in 2022) is essential to our country's social security and health insurance. It provides several benefits to insured persons, such as medical, sickness, and maternity benefits.

Maternity benefits for insured women cover situations such as miscarriage or health issues arising from pregnancy or childbirth. The benefit duration for pregnancy and childbirth is 26 weeks, while for miscarriage, it extends to 6 weeks. Additionally, sickness related to childbirth qualifies for a benefit duration of 30 days.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures favors the maintenance of intestinal continuity at the time of surgery?
questions.solution:
Low anterior resection (LAR) does not involve the creation of a permanent colostomy, thus favors the maintenance of intestinal continuity at the time of surgery.

Low anterior resection (LAR) involves the resection of the rectum below the peritoneal reflection, along with the sigmoid colon, followed by colorectal anastomosis. A temporary diversion stoma may be created but an end colostomy is not created. Low anterior resection (LAR) is the preferred surgery in rectal carcinoma which is located at least 5 - 5.5 cm away from the anal verge.

Other options:

Option A: Hartmann’s procedure refers to colorectal excision with the closure of the distal rectal stump and the creation of a permanent proximal colostomy.

Option C: Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is the complete excision of the rectum and anus by dissecting through the abdomen and perineum followed by the creation of a permanent colostomy.

Option D: Pelvic evisceration is a radical procedure involving the excision of the rectum with all lymph nodes and other pelvic organs including the urinary bladder, uterus and vagina, including surrounding fat and fascia, followed by permanent colostomy and urinary diversion. It is rarely practiced.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of sevoflurane over other anaesthetic agents in the induction of anaesthesia in children?

choices.text: It is less likely to cause seizures
It has a slower onset of action
It is less likely to cause respiratory depression
It is less likely to cause airway irritation

questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is a volatile anaesthetic agent that is preferred for the induction of anaesthesia in children because it is less likely to cause airway irritation.

Children have smaller airways, making them more susceptible to occlusion by secretions and swelling. As a result, even slight airway irritation can cause significant airway obstruction.

The resistance to laminar airflow increases in inverse proportion to the fourth power of the radius (Poiseuille's law). Therefore, a small decrease in the radius of the airway results in a marked increase in resistance to airflow and the work of breathing. Children are more reliant on the diaphragm for inspiration, due to the relative immaturity of the intercostal muscles and accessory muscles.

Sevoflurane also has a faster onset of action than other volatile anaesthetic agents, such as halothane or isoflurane. (Option B) This can be beneficial in children, who may be difficult to restrain during induction. However, it is important to note that sevoflurane can also cause more rapid cardiovascular changes, such as tachycardia and hypotension, during induction. This is because sevoflurane is a more potent vasodilator than other volatile anaesthetic agents.

Other options:

Option A: Sevoflurane is not less likely to cause seizures than other volatile anaesthetic agents. All volatile anaesthetic agents can cause seizures, especially in high doses. 

Option C: Sevoflurane is slightly more likely to cause respiratory depression than other volatile anaesthetic agents, but this is not a major concern in most cases.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old primigravida with a history of diabetes presents with persistent nausea and vomiting at 8 weeks of gestation. She has lost 5% of her pre-pregnancy weight and is unable to tolerate oral fluids. Lab findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Urine ketones = 4+
Fingerstick glucose = 120 mg/dl
questions.solution:
This is a scenario of hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) characterized by persistent nausea, vomiting, dehydration, weight loss, and ketonuria.

Hyperemesis gravidarum is the term for persistent nausea and vomiting. The vomiting is severe enough to result in hypokalemia, ketosis, alkalosis, weight loss, or dehydration. The most common causes are first pregnancies, hydatidiform mole, low body mass, young age, low body mass, history of migraine/motion sickness, positive family history, and multifetal gestation.

Elevations of estrogen and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are part of the pathogenesis. Pregnancy-related increases in oestrogen and progesterone cause the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, which increases the likelihood of experiencing symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), including nausea and vomiting.

Epigastric pain, oliguria, and constipation may occur. Signs include features of dehydration and ketoacidosis such as a dry coated tongue, sunken eyes, acetone smell in breath, tachycardia, and hypotension.

HG can lead to various nutritional deficiencies in the mother leading to Wernicke’s encephalopathy and beriberi due to thiamine deficiency and hypoprothrombinemia due to vitamin K deficiency. Other maternal complications include pontine myelinolysis, stress ulcers, Mallory-Weiss syndrome, jaundice, hepatic failure and renal failure.

Management of HG depends on the severity of the symptoms. Mild to moderate cases can be treated with dietary modifications and vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine. Severe cases require IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral antiemetics. Hydrocortisone or oral prednisolone may also be used in severe cases.

Other Options:

Option A: Simple vomiting of pregnancy (morning sickness) is a normal symptom of pregnancy and is not associated with impairment in activities of daily living, and complications such as weight loss, dehydration 

Option B: Diabetic ketoacidosis is characterized by hyperglycemia(>125mg/dl fasting, >180mg/dl 2 hours postprandial), ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Ovarian torsion is characterized by severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and occurs when the ovary twists on its own blood supply.

questions.text: What is the function of acid alcohol that is used in the Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast staining technique?
questions.solution:
3.0% acid-alcohol (95% ethanol and 3.0% hydrochloric acid) is used for decolorizing.  

Steps involved in the Ziehl-Neelsen stain:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain, staining gently for 5 minutes over direct flame.
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolorized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.


The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for the demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent parts of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • At least 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

Grading of ZN- stained smears for AFB:-

Number of AFB per oil immersion field Grading Number of fields Result
>10 / field 3+ 20 Positive
1-10 / field 2+ 50 Positive
10-99 / 100 field 1+ 100 Positive
1-9 / 100 field Scanty 100 Positive
Nil AFB / 100 field   1000 Negative

questions.text: Which of the following tests is performed to rule out malingering for deafness?
questions.solution:
Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.

Stenger’s test is based on the principle that when sounds of two different intensities are delivered to both ears simultaneously, only the more intense sound is heard.

The patient should ideally be blindfolded. Two tuning forks of equal frequency are struck and placed 25 cm from each ear. The patient might claim to hear it only in the normal ear. Now the tuning fork is brought closer to the supposedly affected ear (within 8 cm) while retaining the position of the tuning fork on the side of the normal ear. The patient who is malingering would claim that he is unable to hear anything even though the tuning fork on the normal side would be in the same position where he claimed to have heard it earlier.

Other options:

Option A: Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis.

Option C: Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.

Option D: Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

A mother brings her infant expressing concern that the baby turns blue whenever he cries. With respect to Nadas' criteria, all of the following findings are used in diagnosing congenital heart disease, except:

ABG - Arterial blood gas
ECG - Electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
Abnormal ABG finding is not included in Nadas' criteria.

Nadas' criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children clinically. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

The major criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur grade 3 or more
  • Any diastolic murmur
  • Cyanosis
  • Congestive cardiac failure

The minor criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2
  • Abnormal second heart sound
  • Abnormal ECG

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after being evacuated from a collapsed building during an earthquake. He is unconscious and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. Imaging of the head reveals the following findings. Which color code will you triage him in?
questions.solution:
The CT scan finding of a biconvex lentiform hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines is suggestive of an extradural hematoma. With a GCS score of 8, the patient should be triaged as red as management requires emergency surgery. 

Triage is done based on a preliminary assessment of patients to determine the urgency of treatment. Patients are prioritized based on the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical treatment. It is particularly useful in case of mass casualties to prevent health facilities from getting overwhelmed. 

Red indicated a high priority of treatment or an immediate transfer to higher health facilities. These patients may survive if they receive timely medical intervention. 

An extradural hematoma with a GCS score of < or = 8 necessitates emergent surgery in the form of craniotomy, hematoma evacuation, and ligation of the injured vessel. Early surgery is associated with good neurological outcomes.

questions.text:
A family presents at a rural PHC with acute onset jaundice and ascites. They consume millet as their primary diet. You suspect food contamination to be the cause of their presentation. Which of the following is the likely contaminant?

PHC: Primary Health Center
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a family presenting with acute onset jaundice and ascites with suspected food contamination is suggestive of endemic ascites. Crotalaria (Jhunjhunia), a weed that grows with millets, is the most likely contaminant.

Endemic ascites is related to the consumption of Crotalaria which contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Clinical features include the rapid development of ascites and jaundice.

Preventive measures against endemic ascites involve educating residents in affected areas. Additional strategies include removing Jhunjhunia plants through deweeding and the household sieving of millets to eliminate Jhunjhunia seeds from the staple.

Other options:

Option A: Lathyrus sativus (khesari dal) is a contaminant of pulses and causes neurolathyrism. The toxin responsible for this condition is beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). Clinical manifestations include the gradual onset of spastic paralysis primarily affecting the lower limbs.

Option C: Claviceps purpurea (ergot fungus) is a contaminant of food grains and causes ergotism. The toxin involved is clavine alkaloids. Acute symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and drowsiness, while chronic exposure leads to painful cramps in limbs and peripheral gangrene.

Option D: Argemone mexicana (prickly poppy) is a contaminant of mustard seeds/ oil and causes epidemic dropsy. The toxin responsible is the alkaloid sanguinarine. Patients with epidemic dropsy exhibit acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of the legs, along with symptoms such as diarrhea, dyspnea, and the risk of cardiac death.

questions.text: Which of the following types of psoriasis cannot be treated with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate can be given in all types of psoriasis except impetigo herpetiformis, also known as acute generalized pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. The drug of choice for impetigo herpetiformis is systemic steroids.

Impetigo herpetiformis typically presents during the last trimester of pregnancy. It may persist until the delivery of the child, however, it may even persist longer. Clinical features include:

  • Characteristic erythematous patches with marginal grouped sterile pustules
  • Flexures affected, symmetrical
  • Centrifugal extension from the inguino-genital region
  • Grouping of areas of pustulation
  • Erosions and crusts may be present
  • Residual reddish-brown pigmentation as healing occurs.
  • Nail, mucosal lesions in tongue, mouth, and oesophagus
  • May be associated with hypothyroidism and hypocalcemia

Below is an image showing annular lesions on the left thigh of a patient with pustular psoriasis of pregnancy. 

The mainstay of treatment is systemic corticosteroids. If unresponsive to corticosteroids, cyclosporine can also be started. Antibiotics like cephalosporins are found to be effective as an additive treatment, even though the pustules are sterile. Narrowband UVB is considered another safe treatment when there is not an adequate response to steroids.

Complications like intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), premature rupture of membranes (PROM), and placental insufficiency are also seen. Death of the mother may occur due to cardiac or renal failure. Recurrence is common.
