questions.text: A patient being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following will decrease mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Long-term oxygen therapy will decrease mortality in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). 

Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting O2 saturation of ≤88% or ≤89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day). Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia. 

Patients with dependent edema, P-pulmonale on ECG, or hematocrit value >56% with PaO2 value between 56-59 mm Hg or SaO2 of 89% are also eligible for oxygen therapy.

COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction.  It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Patients present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. Diagnosis is based on pulmonary function tests and the severity is graded according to the global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease (GOLD) criteria. 

Pharmacotherapy of COPD includes:

  • Muscarinic antagonists: ipratropium, tiotropium
  • Beta-agonists: salbutamol, salmeterol
  • Theophylline
  • Inhaled corticosteroids

Acute exacerbations are managed with inhaled beta-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, oxygen, mechanical ventilation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation, and antibiotics.

Smoking cessation and lung volume reduction surgery in some emphysematous patients are the other interventions associated with reduced mortality.

Other options:

Option 2: Long-term oral glucocorticoids are not recommended to treat COPD due to the significant adverse effects such as osteoporosis, weight gain, and cataracts.

Option 3: Inhaled corticosteroids are mainly used to reduce exacerbations. Patients with two or more exacerbations per year or hospitalized patients with one exacerbation can be considered. 

Option 4: Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors (PDE4) inhibitor roflumilast can be used to reduce the frequency of exacerbations in severe COPD and chronic bronchitis.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The bony structure depicted in the image is the incus, which can be identified from its anvil shape,  the presence of a short process and a vertically hanging long process, and it is derived embryologically from the first pharyngeal arch.

The ear ossicles - malleus, incus, and stapes, are the three bones of the middle ear which conduct sound energy from the tympanic membrane to the oval window and the inner ear fluid. 

The malleus is the largest of the three and is hammer shaped. The handle of the malleus is attached to the upper half of the tympanic membrane and the head is attached to the incus. The incus is the middle bone, as described above. The stapes is the smallest and medial most ossicle, which is stirrup shaped, with two distinct limbs and a footplate attached to the oval window. 

The first pharyngeal arch is known as the mandibular arch. The artery associated with the first arch is the maxillary artery and the nerve supply is provided by the maxillary and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

The derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch are

i. Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences,

Mandibular prominence (ventral)- The mandibular prominence has two components:

  • Meckel's cartilage- It forms the malleus, incus, spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments.
  • Mesenchyme surrounding the Meckel's cartilage undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible.

Maxillary prominence (dorsal). The mesenchyme of this process forms the maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone.

ii. Muscular derivatives include:

  • tensor tympani
  • tensor veli palatini
  • muscles of mastication
  • anterior belly of digastric
  • mylohyoid

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia presents with a dark, velvety thickening of the skin around his neck as shown in the image below. Which of the following hormones is most likely associated with this darkening?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a patient with darkening of the skin of the neck suggesting acanthosis nigricans (AN). This results from the excess insulin that binds to insulin-like growth factor (IGF) receptors on keratinocytes and stimulates their growth (hyperinsulinemia directly stimulates keratinocytes).

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. It is more common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity, hypertension, and dyslipiemdia (metabolic syndrome; as seen in this patient) are the most common associations with AN which is reversible with weight loss. It is also found to be more common in patients with darker skin tones.

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae called papillomatosis. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or melanin production. 

Acanthosis nigricans can only be treated by treating the underlying disease. In addition, treatment specific to acanthosis nigricans is done for aesthetic reasons.  Medications like keratolytics, topical vitamin D, and melatonin can be used. Procedures like laser, dermabrasion, and chemical peels are also available. 

Other options:

Option B: Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH) secretion can lead to hyperpigmentation due to melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) stimulation in adrenocortical insufficiency (eg. Addison's disease). One of the characteristic features of Addison's illness is the presence of excessive pigmentation on the skin and mucous membranes, which is caused by the action of ACTH on melanocytes. The earliest lesions occur in the oral mucosa. The absence of these findings as well as other features of Addisons (fatigue, weight loss or anorexia) in this patient points to a different diagnosis.

Option C: Melasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is most marked in brunettes. It occurs due to increased levels of estrogen and progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes with melanocyte-stimulating hormone. It resolves on its own after pregnancy. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead, and the chin. The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma. 

Option D: Vascular endothelial growth factor is commonly associated with hemangiomas, benign tumours that are made up of blood vessels. Hemangiomas can occur anywhere on the body, but they are most common on the head, neck, and face. Below is an illustration depicting the presence of hemangiomas on a child’s arm.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic diarrhea and weight loss was evaluated for malabsorption syndromes. Small-intestine biopsy showed PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. What is the probable diagnosis?

PAS - Periodic acid schiff
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Whipple's disease. Histology shows characteristic PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. The causative bacilli (Tropheryma whipplei) can be seen both inside the macrophages and extracellularly on biopsy.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with the central nervous system and cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by arthralgias, weight loss, chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction are other sensitive investigations.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone or meropenem. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.

 

Other options:

Option A- Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. A small intestinal biopsy will show characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Serology will show the presence of antibodies against tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. This disease responds well to a gluten-free diet. 

Option C- Tropical sprue also manifests as chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiencies. Histologic findings are similar to those of celiac disease. However, it does not respond to a gluten-free diet.

Option D- Small bowel bacterial overgrowth occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the bacterial count in the intestine. It occurs in conditions affecting the motility of the intestine, like scleroderma. Duodenal aspirate shows bacterial overgrowth. Breath hydrogen testing with lactulose can also diagnose the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure labeled as '3' in the given image?

All three divisions of this nerve are related to the cavernous sinus
It innervates the dura mater of all three cranial fossae
It arises from the dorsal surface of the brainstem

questions.solution:
The structure that is labelled as '3' in the image is the trigeminal nerve (V) which innervates the dura mater of all three cranial fossae. Below is an illustration of all cranial nerves at the floor of the skull.

The nerve branches supplying the dura mater in each cranial fossa are:

  • Maxillary division (V2)- nervus meningeus medius

Other options:

Option B: The ophthalmic and the maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve are present in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.It is worth noting that the mandibular nerve is not related to the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the pattern of respiration in a 55-year-old man. Identify the pattern of breathing and its associated possible cause.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s breathing and one of its associated causes includes sepsis.

Kussmaul’s breathing is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually due to metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

Normally, the H+ ions from acids in our body are buffered with various mechanisms. But in cases, where acid production is high like in diabetic ketoacidosis and sepsis, the buffering capacity is exceeded. The resulting acidosis stimulates respiration and decreases alveolar CO2 in order to produce a compensatory fall in the H+ ions.

Other options:

Option A. Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 

Options B: Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnoea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia. This pattern of breathing is associated with increased sensitivity to arterial PCO2 and prolonged lung-to-brain circulation time.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the median effective dose (ED50) of a drug used to induce sleep?

choices.text: It is the median dose able to elicit sleep induction
It is the dose with a 50% probability of causing sleep
It is the dose that elicits sleep in 50% of subjects
It is half of the dose required for sleep induction

questions.solution:
The median effective dose (ED50) refers to the dosage level at which a specific effect is observed in 50% of the participants.

ED50 is a measure of the drug's potency.

questions.text: You are counseling a mother on the benefits of breastfeeding. All of the following statements are true regarding breast milk, except

choices.text: It contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine
It has a higher protein content compared to animal milk
It is rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids
It contains several factors protective against infections

questions.solution:
The protein content of breast milk is lower as compared to animal milk. Hence, option B is not true. 

Breast milk is an ideal food for infants in the first 6 months of life. It contains all the required nutrients for normal growth and development. It has a high concentration of lactose, which is necessary for the formation of galactocerebrosides. It is rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids (option C). Both of these factors are essential for the normal development of the nervous system.

The protein content of breast milk is lower as compared to animal milk. However, it is superior in quality and digestibility. Amino acids like taurine and cysteine, crucial for brain development, are present in breast milk (option A) but absent in cow's milk. 

Breast milk is rich in protective components such as secretory IgA, macrophages, lymphocytes, and lactoferrin. These serve to protect infants from infections and decrease their susceptibility to conditions like diarrhea and respiratory illnesses (option D). Breast milk also contains several growth factors promoting intestinal maturation. 

Breastfeeding also provides benefits for the mother. It reduces the risk of postpartum depression for mothers. It promotes bonding and emotional development between the mother and the baby. It also protects against pregnancy due to lactational amenorrhea.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Which subtype of breast carcinoma among the following shows a loss of E-cadherin expression?
questions.solution:
Lobular carcinoma subtype of breast carcinoma shows a loss of E-cadherin expression.

Lobular carcinoma of the breast is characterized by biallelic loss of expression of CDH1, the gene responsible for encoding E-cadherin. These carcinomas display dyscohesive behavior, infiltrating as individual cells. Additionally, their tendency to sometimes lack a desmoplastic response makes it difficult to detect them clinically. 

E-cadherin is a transmembrane protein essential for maintaining cohesion among normal epithelial cells in the breast and other glandular tissues. It acts as a tumor suppressor protein and is lost in cases of lobular carcinoma.

In lobular carcinoma of the breast, the histopathological examination shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern.

The image below shows the single file pattern seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast:


Other options:

Option B: Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with mutations and reduced expression of BRCA1. 

Option C: Inflammatory carcinoma is a diffusely infiltrative carcinoma caused by the extensive invasion of the lymphovascular space. It carries a poor prognosis. It presents with breast erythema, swelling, and skin thickening. It is unlikely to be associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression.

Option D: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a neoplastic proliferation of epithelial cells limited by the basement membrane. It involves the ducts and lobules. It is not associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is surgically treated by Bascom’s procedure?
questions.solution:
Pilonidal sinus can be surgically managed by Bascom’s procedure which is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia.

A sinus is defined as a blind track lined by granulation tissue leading from an epithelial surface to surrounding tissue. Pilonidal sinus disease, also called jeep/driver’s bottom, is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty.

Buttock friction and shearing forces (drivers are commonly affected) in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine. A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.

Treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches:

Non-surgical approaches include conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised.

Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:

  • Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment.
  • Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia
  • Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty.
  • Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a fascio-cutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect. Below is an image depiticing the same.
  • Limberg/rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a fascio-cutaneous flap for wound closure. Below is an image depiticing the same.

Other options:

Option A: Pre-auricular sinus is treated by complete surgical excision of the track.

Option B: Thyroglossal fistula is surgically treated by Sistrunk’s operation.

Option D: Fistula-in-ano is surgically managed by fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the inter-sphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), or setons.

questions.text: The PCSK-9 inhibitor used for lowering lipid in the body is __________.
questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9. 

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against integrin α4 used in multiple sclerosis.

Option B: Efalizumab is an anti–LFA–1 antibody used in psoriasis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF-α Monoclonal Antibody used in inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes the epidemiologic data received from field investigations and surveillance by using the chart given below. Which of the following examples best represents the chart shown in the image?

choices.text: Gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker

questions.solution:
The chart in the image shows an epidemic curve that rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves. This is indicative of a point-source epidemic. Among the given options, an epidemic of food poisoning is the best example of a point-source epidemic.

Point-source epidemics are also called single-exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics. The exposure to the disease agent is brief, and all cases develop within one incubation period. Single-exposure outbreaks are explosive, with clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. Infectious agents, environmental pollution, and food contamination are common causes of point-source epidemics.

Common-source, single-exposure epidemics are differentiated from common-source, multiple-exposure epidemics as follows:

  Common-source, single-exposure epidemic Common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Other options:

Options B and C - Outbreak of Legionnaire's disease and a gonorrhea outbreak from a sex worker are examples of a common-source, multiple-exposure epidemic. The exposure from the same source may be prolonged—continuous, repeated, or intermittent—and not at the same time or place. There is no single explosive increase in the number of cases.

Option D - Epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) is an example of propagated epidemics that result from the transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A  woman presents with a 6-month history of cough, dyspnea, and fatigue. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. She has hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray. Which of the following parameters are likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms, along with hypercalcemia and chest X-ray findings raise suspicion for Sarcoidosis. ACE levels are elevated in this condition as sarcoid granulomas secrete it.

Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in Sarcoidosis, Silicosis, Leprosy, Gaucher’s disease, Hyperthyroidism and Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

Two syndromes are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome characterised by bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Chest X-ray findings include:

  • The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.
  • Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.
  • It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE.
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Serum amylase levels are elevated in conditions that affect the pancreas or salivary glands, such as pancreatitis, cancer, sialolithiasis or in the case of Mickulicz syndrome with involvement of the parotid glands.

Option C: Serum calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option D: Serum PTH levels are elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in - 

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS – can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis
  • Papillary and medullary Ca thyroid

questions.text: In which of the following patients is it least advisable for the following airway maneuver to be performed?

choices.text: A 44 year old patient that suddenly collapsed in his chair and is now unresponsive
A 9 year old child that suddenly collapsed during jogging and is now unresponsive
A 23 year old patient that fell from height and is now unresponsive
A 62 year old diabetic patient that collapse in the ward and is now unresponsive

questions.solution:
The airway manoeuvre shown is the head tilt and the chin lift. This should not be performed in those with a suspected cervical spine injury. It is prudent to exclude the manoeuvre from the medical plan of a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury after a fall from a height. 

Basic life support (BLS) involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. In such cases a head tilt, chin lift manouver may be performed. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead, applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat. Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

A jaw thrust can be performed in a patient with cervical injury, but caution must be exercised to not hyperextend the neck. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head, and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a tender, fluctuant swelling over the left scapular region. A visible pus point is seen. Which of the following is false about the management of this condition in this patient?

choices.text: Incision is parallel to underlying neurovascular bundle
The wound is usually not sutured
No. 24 blade is usually used for the incision
Local anesthetic is not completely effective

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an abscess. A No. 11 surgical blade (stab knife) is always the preferred blade for use in an incision and drainage for an abscess. This blade can also be used for inserting drains and arteriotomy. Given below are the various surgical blades with their sizes.

An abscess is defined as a localized collection of pus in a cavity lined by granulation tissue. Clinically, a formed abscess presents as a warm, erythematous, tender, fluctuant swelling with a visible pus point. 

The definitive management of an abscess is by incision and drainage of the abscess cavity by Hilton’s method. A linear incision at the most dependent position of the abscess, placed parallel to the neurovascular bundle (Option A), or a cruciate incision over the abscess is employed. All the pus is allowed to drain and a sample should be sent for microbiological culture and sensitivity. The abscess cavity is cleared of all loculations, using sinus forceps or the tip of the finger. The cavity is then packed with betadine-soaked sterile gauze and the wound is not sutured (Option B) but allowed to heal by secondary intention. 

It must be remembered that local anesthetics act in a basic or alkaline environment and hence may not be completely effective in an abscess as pus is acidic, and a higher dose or wider block around the surgical site might be needed. (Option D)

questions.text: The graph shown below depicts a type of gastrointestinal movement. This movement is initiated by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex (MMC), which is initiated by the hormone motilin.

MMC is a type of gastrointestinal motility that occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. It is initiated by motilin. It helps to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal. Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC.

After ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases:

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy had abdominal pain for the past 1 week and associated swelling of his knees with non-blanching rashes. His platelet levels were normal. What is the probable immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a boy presenting with abdominal pain, swelling of knees, non-blanching rashes, and a normal platelet count is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. Vasculitis occurs due to immune complex depositions involving IgA. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. Renal manifestations vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show a mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. IgA and C3 complements are elevated in the serum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of severe psoriasis is being planned on an IL-12/23 inhibitor. Which of the following drugs is she most likely to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ustekinumab is a fully human IgG1  monoclonal antibody against the p40 subunit that is common to both IL‐12 and IL‐23. 

Ustekinumab is indicated for severe plaque psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and Crohn's disease. Dizziness, sore throat and joint pain are the most common side effects associated with Ustekinumab. Ustekinumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection every 12 weeks.

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α  Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
  • Etanercept 
  • Adalimumab 
  • Golimumab
  • Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 Secukinumab
Anti-IL-23 and IL-12 Ustekinumab

 

Other options:

Option B: Secukinumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-17A cytokine. It is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe plaque psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. Secukinumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection every 4 or 12 weeks.

Option C: Ixekizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-17A cytokine. It is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe plaque psoriasis in adults. Ixekizumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection every 4 weeks.

Option D: Brodalumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-17RA receptor. It is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. Brodalumab is administered as a subcutaneous injection every 2 weeks. It leads to black tarry stools, lethargy and joint pain as the most common adverse effects.

questions.text: What is the position of the vocal cords in normal quiet respiration?
questions.solution:
The vocal cords are in slight (or gentle) abduction during normal quiet respiration, which is about 7 mm from the midline. Slight abduction of vocal cords is also seen in adductor paralysis.

Other options: 

Option A: Paramedian position of vocal cords (1.5 mm from the midline) is seen normally during a strong whisper. It is also seen in recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

Option B: Intermediate, or cadaveric position of vocal cords (3.5 mm from midline) is seen in paralysis of both RLN and superior laryngeal nerves. It is the neutral position of the cricoaretynoid joint.

Option D: Full abduction (9.5 mm from the midline) of vocal cords is seen normally during deep inspiration.

questions.text: Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes, crazy pavement pattern on HRCT, and progressive massive fibrosis are most likely to be associated with which of the following pneumoconioses?
questions.solution:
Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes, crazy pavement pattern on HRCT, and progressive massive fibrosis are most likely to be associated with silicosis.

Silicosis is a common concern for people working in granite mining industries. Silica is found in rock, granite, slate, and sandstone. People working in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying are exposed to silica. The active molecule that causes silicosis is free silica or crystalline silica (quartz).

Silicosis can present as:

  • Acute silicosis - due to heavy exposure in closed spaces and they manifest within 2 years.
  • Chronic silicosis (simple silicosis) - due to long-term (10 to 30 years), less intense exposure.
  • Complicated silicosis - simple silicosis may progress to complicated silicosis that presents with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion.

Calcification of hilar lymph nodes leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes, and there is no impairment in lung function. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) and is associated with significant impairment of lung function.

Note: Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world.

questions.text: A 30-year-old accident victim is brought with a blood pressure of 70/40mmHg. Her vitals have not improved with crystalloids. Her blood samples were sent for typing and cross-matching. In view of the blunted response to crystalloids, which packed red blood cells can she receive until the cross-matched blood arrives?
questions.solution:
O negative packed red blood cells (pRBCs) can be given to this female patient till the cross-matched blood is available.

To prevent transfusion reactions, donor and recipients' blood are cross-matched for ABO and rhesus antigens to ensure compatibility. Cross-matching of blood usually takes up to 45 minutes.

In urgent situations, type-specific blood with ABO and rhesus antigens matched is provided within 10-15 minutes. In more emergencies where blood is to be given immediately, group O (universal donor) can be given (O negative to females and O positive to males). To avoid rhesus sensitization and future complications, Rh-negative pRbC is preferred for females of the reproductive age group.

The decreasing order of preference of pRBCs is cross-matched blood > type-specific blood > type O blood.

Group AB plasma is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed.

Massive transfusion is required in some patients of shock where > 10 units of pRbCs within the first 24 hours of admission or > 4 units of blood in 1 hour is transfused. Complications of massive transfusion include:

  • coagulopathy
  • hypocalcemia
  • hyperkalemia
  • hypokalemia
  • hypothermia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient comes with complaints of missing IUCD threads. She had an IUCD inserted 6 months ago. The threads are not visible on speculum examination. Imaging reveals IUCD in the uterine cavity. What would be the next step in management?

choices.text: Remove only if signs of infection present

questions.solution:
Removal of misplaced IUCD that is confirmed to be present in the uterine cavity should be removed using Shirodkar’s hook.

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy, curling of the threads inside the uterus, perforation of the uterus, IUCD buried in the myometrium and spontaneous expulsion. Pelvic ultrasound would be the initial investigation of choice to confirm the location of a missing IUCD.

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include insertion by less experienced clinicians, postpartum insertion (<6 months since delivery), higher number of previous abortions, lower parity and lactation.

If the location of the IUCD is found to be inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook, curette, or hysteroscopy with ultrasound guidance.

In the case of uterine perforation, a laparotomy (Option A) is done as a copper-T can adhere to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to remove using a laparoscope.

Other Options:

Option C: A misplaced IUCD is removed even if signs of infection are not present.

Option D: Waiting for spontaneous expulsion of the misplaced IUCD is not indicated as there is a risk of perforation or infection.

questions.text: Identify the correct match.
questions.solution:
Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for anal fissure at present.

An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate line and extending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic. Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with:

  • Anal pain
  • Spasm
  • Bleeding with defecation

The initial treatment of anal fissures includes: Frequent sitz baths, analgesics, stool softners and high-fiber diet.

Other options include topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted. 

Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique. 

Other options:

Option a: Delorme procedure is for rectal prolapse.

Option b: Seton procedure is for fistula in ano.

Option d: Nigro regimen is for anal carcinoma.

questions.text: A newborn with transposition of great vessels is being planned for surgery, and Alprostadil is administered in the interim to maintain the ductus arteriosus. This drug is also used for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for temporarily maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates and it is also indicated in patients not responding to phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors (sildenafil, tadalafil, etc) eg. patients with neurogenic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction.

Alprostadil is a natural prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of smooth muscle. It is available as an intraurethral suppository and intracavernosal injection. Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

Other Prostaglandins (PG) analogues:

PGE1: Misoprostol is approved for the termination of pregnancy, and the prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.
PGE2: Dinoprostone is used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and as abortifacients in the second trimester of pregnancy. (Option D)
PGI2: Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in pulmonary artery hypertension. Iloprost and Treprostinil used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.
PGF2α: Carboprost is used to induce second-trimester abortions and to control postpartum hemorrhage. Latanoprost is a long-acting PGF2α derivative, used for glaucoma. (Option B) Similar prostanoids with ocular hypotensive effects include bimatoprost, tafluprost, and travoprost.

Other option(s):

Option A: Prostaglandin analogues are not indicated in the treatment of systemic hypertension.

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 122 beats/min. The baby coughs on inserting a nasal catheter and has a strong cry. His limbs have some degree of flexion and his body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this newborn is 8.

In the given newborn the following features bring the total Apgar score to 8: 

  • Heart rate >100 - score 2
  • Strong cry is present in terms of respiratory effort - score 2
  • Body appears pink but the extremities are blue - score 1
  • Some degree of flexion - score 1
  • Coughs on stimulation - score 2

Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration.  It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Haemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding stage (stage 2). 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rates and death rates within a population, leading to changes in population size and age structure.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, the following finding is noticed over the abdomen. His laboratory reports indicate excessive secretion of a specific adrenal hormone. This hormone is physiologically elevated in all of the following conditions, except ____.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with hypertension, moon facies, easy bruisability, and multiple purple striae over the abdomen is consistent with Cushing's syndrome. The adrenal hormone implicated is cortisol and cortisol levels are physiologically elevated around early morning while waking up.

Cushing's syndrome can be ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent. When it is caused by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secreting tumor of the pituitary gland, it is called Cushing's disease. 

ACTH is a hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. Its secretion is controlled by corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. In turn, ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce cortisol.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Cushing syndrome.

The rate of secretion and levels of cortisol are high in the morning but low in the evening. Specifically, its levels are the highest about an hour before waking up in the morning and lowest around midnight. This occurs due to a cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus, over 24 hours.

Additionally, during a mentally stressful state and when pain causes physical stress, there is an increase in cortisol levels in the body.

The diurnal variation of cortisol production is shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Side effects of Corticosteroids: mnemonic "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a red, sharply demarcated, and confluent rash in her diaper area as shown in the image below. The infant has been having diarrhea and his mother administered antibiotics for the past 10 days. She is otherwise well and is feeding well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The red, sharply demarcated, confluent rash with tiny, superficial, pustular satellite lesions with noticeable extension into the inguinal folds which did not resolve with antibiotics suggests a diagnosis of candida diaper dermatitis. Involvement of the skinfolds helps differentiate this condition from irritant contact dermatitis (spares skinfolds).

Candida diaper dermatitis is a common fungal infection of the diaper area. It is caused by the yeast Candida albicans. Risk factors include prolonged diaper use, diarrhoea, and antibiotic use. The immature immune system of neonates, the presence of Candida albicans in normal gut flora and the moist and occluded environment of the diaper area predispose neonates to candida diaper dermatitis.

Treatment for Candida diaper dermatitis is typically topical antifungal medications, such as clotrimazole or miconazole. In severe cases, oral antifungal medications may be necessary.

Diaper dermatitis occurs commonly in neonates. The most common causes are irritant contact dermatitis and candidal rash. These are mostly clinical diagnoses and since the treatment for these two differ, it becomes imperative to be able to differentiate the two.

Diagnosis Irritant Contact dermatitis Candida dermatitis
Occurrence Most common Second most common
Physical exam

Macerated skin usually from stool/urine

Skin folds spared

Beefy, bright red rash

Satellite lesions

Involves skin folds
Treatment Barrier creams, Zinc Oxide Topical Antifungals (Oral if severe)

Other options: 

Option B: Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the scalp and other oily areas of the body, such as the face, chest, and back. It is not typically seen in the diaper area.

Option C: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that is characterized by dry, itchy skin. It is often seen in the flexural areas of the body, such as the elbows and knees, but it is not typically seen in the diaper area. 

Option D: Irritant contact dermatitis can be treated with zinc oxide. It is a non-infectious rash caused by prolonged exposure to irritants, such as urine and faeces. Physical examination demonstrates erythema in the diaper region that spares the skinfolds and no satellite lesions. It typically does not extend to the inguinal folds.

questions.text: A patient has come for a follow-up for ectopic pregnancy after having received a single dose of methotrexate IM injection. Drop in β hCG is <5% on day 7.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Following the administration of methotrexate, mean beta hCG levels may rise during the first 4 days followed by a gradual decline. A repeat dose is required if the decline in beta hCG is less than 15% between days 4 and 7.

If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly (Option B) till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. 

Medical management is preferred in the cases of low initial serum beta-hCG level (<5,000 IU/L), small ectopic pregnancy size (<4 cm), absent fetal cardiac activity and if hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency department following a dog bite. Which of the following is false regarding the intramuscular (IM) vaccine administration in post-exposure prophylaxis for rabies?

choices.text: Deltoid muscle in the recommended site in adults
Anterolateral thigh is recommended for children below 2 years of age
The gluteal region is an acceptable alternative site in adults
IM injection is preferred over intradermal injection in patients on chloroquine

questions.solution:
The rabies vaccine should never be injected into the gluteal region as it results in lower neutralizing antibody titers. 

The intramuscular regimens for post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies involve injecting 1 ml or 0.5 ml (depending on the type of vaccine) into the deltoid muscle in adults (option A) or the anterolateral thigh in children below 2 years of age (option B). This is applicable for both category II and category III exposures. The recommended regimens are as follows:

  • Essen regimen: A 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28.
  • Zagreb regimen: A 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, followed by 1 dose on days 7 and 21.

The intradermal regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis is a 2-site regimen where 0.1 ml of the vaccine is injected at 2 sites (deltoid or thigh) on days 0, 3, 7, and 28.

Patients on chloroquine for malaria treatment or prophylaxis may have a reduced response to intradermal vaccination. Hence, intramuscular administration is preferred for such individuals (option D).

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A elderly male patient complains of chest pain at rest. He previously experienced it on exertion. ECG shows ST depression, with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina based on the clinical features given. Unstable angina is a subtype of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

ACS includes:

1. Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

  • Unstable angina
  • Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

2. ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The former, which includes unstable angina arises due to an imbalance in the myocardial oxygen supply-demand ratio. They present with characteristic features such as chest pain at rest, of recent onset, and lasting for more than ten minutes. It usually lasts longer or is more severe than previous episodes. (crescendo pattern). The pain is usually retrosternal and might radiate to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw. 

ECG may show new ST-segment depression in one-third of the patients. It can be transient or may last for several days in NSTEMI. In unstable angina, there is no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, namely cardiac troponin I or cardiac troponin T. In other words, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis.

Stable angina is marked by ischemic episodes which present as chest pain, precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest. 

Other options:

Option A: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, a component of ACS, presents with similar symptoms. In contrast to unstable angina, there are elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers.

Option B: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, occurs due to occlusion of a coronary artery by thrombus. Usually, these vessels are already affected by atherosclerosis. The chest pain may last for more than 30 minutes, associated with marked diaphoresis. The ECG initially shows ST-segment elevation, and usually develops Q waves later on. There is an elevation of cardiac biomarkers. 

Option C: Left heart failure, which arises due to pulmonary edema, presents with shortness of breath. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and N-terminal pro-BNP are biomarkers that are usually elevated. There are no specific ECG changes. Any abnormality can rather point to the underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category C agent?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus is a category C bioterrorism agent.

Bioterrorism is the intentional release or threat of release of biological agents (i.e. viruses, bacteria, fungi, or their toxins) in order to cause disease or death among the human population or food crops and livestock to terrorize a civilian population or manipulate the government. 

The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts.

Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum and Yersinia pestis.

Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates.

Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.

Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination.

Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: The dose-response curve is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not include as a differential diagnosis for a swelling that moves with deglutition?
questions.solution:
A plunging ranula does not move with deglutition.

A ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst originating from the sublingual gland in the floor of the mouth due to obstruction of its duct. A cervical or plunging ranula occurs when the mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm and enters the neck, presenting as a painless, enlarging neck mass, which does not move with deglutition.

Neck swellings that are attached to the larynx or trachea move with deglutition. Examples include thyroid swellings, thyroglossal cyst (Option A), sub-hyoid bursitis (Option C) and pre- or para-tracheal lymph nodes (Option D).

Other options:

Option A: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. Normally, the thyroglossal duct regresses once the thyroid gland has completely descended. If it fails to regress, a thyroglossal duct cyst is formed. It can move with deglutition.

Option C: Inflammation of the bursa just beneath the hyoid bone can lead to subhyoid bursitis. It tends to move with deglutition.

Option D: Paratracheal lymph nodes in the neck are located laterally to the trachea and esophagus, adjacent to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is also known to move with deglutition.

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a large painless scrotal swelling. On examination, the testes are not felt separately, and the swelling is fluctuant and transilluminant. Which of the following is NOT a surgical procedure used to correct this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis from the above scenario is primary hydrocele. Fowler-Stephen’s technique refers to the technique of orchidopexy which involves the division of the testicular artery and is used to treat cryotorchidism.

A hydrocele occurs as a result of the buildup of fluid between the two layers of the tunica vaginalis. It can be classified as either primary or secondary, depending on whether it is caused by a malfunction in absorbing excessive formation. Hydrocele is a condition characterized by a swelling that tightly surrounds the testis and epididymis, rendering them unable to be felt. Palpating a normal spermatic cord can be achieved by elevating above the swelling in hydrocele.

Etiology of hydrocele and types:

  • Primary (vaginal)- due to defective absorption of fluid.
  • Secondary hydrocele- due to excessive production of fluid in the sac.
  • Congenital- through connection with the peritoneal cavity via patent processus vaginalis.
  • Due to interference of lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures.

Surgery constitutes the definitive method of hydrocele management. The surgical options are:

  • Lord's procedure (Option B)- wherein the redundant tunica is plicated.
  • Jaboulay's procedure (Option C) - excision and eversion of the sac upon itself.
  • Sharma and Jhawer’s technique (Option D) - sac and testes placed in a new pocket within fascial layers of the scrotum

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient recently began to display flattening of affect and social withdrawal. Which medication would most likely address his recent onset symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's new onset of symptoms of social withdrawal and flattening of affect can be addressed with the use of olanzapine.

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that blocks both serotonin (5HT2A) and dopamine (D2) receptors. Olanzapine and other atypical antipsychotics are efficacious in reducing negative symptoms (flattening affect and social withdrawal) of schizophrenia. 

Olanzapine is a weak dopamine antagonist and therefore has fewer extrapyramidal side effects. However, because of the serotonin blockade, Olanzapine is prone to higher metabolic side effects (eg. weight gain, glucose intolerance).

Other options:

Option B: Sertraline is an antidepressant and is not used in the treatment of schizophrenia.

Option C: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic that would be less effective in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia. 

Option D: Lithium is a mood stabilizer and is not used in the treatment of schizophrenia.

Recent research has reported that haloperidol is effective in the treatment of negative symptoms, particularly affective flattening and alogia, but olanzapine is chosen as the answer because of its more documented efficacy over haloperidol.

questions.text: Branches from which of the following vessels form the vascular pedicle for a latissimus dorsi flap?
questions.solution:
The vascular pedicle for the latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is based on the thoracodorsal artery, which is a branch of the subscapular artery.

A surgical flap is used to transfer tissue with its blood supply, from a donor area, to reconstruct a defect in the recipient artery. A flap is composed of a base, pedicle and tip, and the pedicle contains the blood supply. Flaps are broadly classified as follows:

  • Advancement flap

  • Free flap

Simple Flap

  • Cutaneous flap
  • Musculocutaneous 
  • Fasciocutaneous

 

Composite flap

  • Osseocutaneous flap
  • Sensory flap

 

Other options:

Option B: A pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (PMMF) is based on the pectoral branches of the thoraco-acromial artery.

Option C: A serratus anterior flap is based on the lateral thoracic artery.

Option D: A deltopectoral flap (Bakamjian flap) is based on the perforating branches of the internal mammary artery.

questions.text: As a public health officer, you are evaluating the implementation of the expanded program on immunization (EPI) covering 9 diseases. You assess the proportion of infants in the community who are fully immunized under this program. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The proportion of fully immunized infants against the 9 Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) diseases is an example of utilization rates.

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period. It gives an indication of the care needed and the health status of a population. The utilization rates are affected by the availability and accessibility of health services and public health awareness. 

The following are examples of utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of pregnant women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate (average daily in-patient census) at a healthcare facility 
  • Average length of stay at a hospital
  • Bed turnover ratio (discharges/average beds) at a hospital

Other options:

Option A: Health care delivery indicators reflect the provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country. Examples: Doctor- population ratio, Doctor-nurse ratio

Option B: Indicators of quality of life are difficult to define or measure. The physical quality of life index is an example that consolidates three indicators, i.e., infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy. 

Option D: Basic needs indicators are indicators involving "basic needs performance," i.e; calorie consumption, access to water, life expectancy, deaths due to disease, illiteracy, etc

questions.text: A patient has dementia, Parkinsonism, and visual hallucinations. Lewy body dementia is suspected. Which of the following represents the pathologic deposits and the site involved in this condition?

choices.text: Alpha-synuclein aggregates in the hippocampus and parahippocampal gyrus
Tau protein tangles in the amygdala and entorhinal cortex
Amyloid plaques in the hippocampus and basal gangli
Misfolded PrP in the hippocampus and basal ganglia

questions.solution:
Alpha-synuclein is an unfolded protein that aggregates in Lewy Body Dementia, particularly in the subcortical regions and in the hippocampus and parahippocampal gyrus. 

The pathophysiology of this condition is characterized by the presence of eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions called Lewy bodies. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions more than the cortex.  

Lewy body dementia is a progressive neurodegenerative associated with dementia, psychosis, and features of parkinsonism. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies and they mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways. The hippocampus and parahippocampal gyrus are important brain regions for memory and cognition.

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is diagnosed when at least 2 of the core diagnostic features are present:

  • Fluctuating cognitive decline of memory, attention, concentration, or awareness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (hallmark) typically are well-formed and detailed.
  • Parkinsonian features like tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, festinating gait and mask-like facies. These motor symptoms present at the late stages of the disease.

Suggestive features include sleep disturbances - rapid eye movement, behavioural disorder, sensitivity to neuroleptics, and decreased dopamine uptake in basal ganglia. Other symptoms include mood disorders and autonomic disturbances. 

A PET or SPECT scan shows reduced dopamine transporter uptake in the cortical/subcortical areas of the brain. 123 Iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy (MIBG) reveals reduced postganglionic sympathetic cardiac innervation. Polysomnography and EEG (electroencephalogram) confirm REM sleep behaviour disorders. Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) of less than 25 indicates neurocognitive decline.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management which includes:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil treat cognitive impairments
  • Antidepressants like SSRIs to treat depression and sleep disorders
  • Atypical antipsychotics like Quetiapine to treat psychotic symptoms.
  • Supportive care such as physiotherapy, exercise, and/or family therapies are also encouraged.

Highly potent typical antipsychotics like Haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

Other options:

Option B: Neurofibrillary tangles are made up of a protein called tau. Tau tangles are a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease, but they can also be seen in Lewy body dementia, especially in cases with coexistent Alzheimer's pathology. 

Option C: Amyloid plaques are made up of a protein called amyloid beta. Amyloid plaques are a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease, but they can also be seen in Lewy body dementia, especially in cases with coexistent Alzheimer's pathology.

Option D: Misfolded prion proteins that can cause other proteins to misfold; seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakub disease. Prion diseases are rapidly progressive, fatal and incurable.
