questions.text: An external cephalic version is done for conversion of breech presentation in an Rh-negative pregnant woman at 38 weeks gestation. What is the dose of anti-D that needs to be given after the procedure?

choices.text: No anti-D dose needs to be given

questions.solution:
1500 IU (300 mcg) should be given after performing an external cephalic version in Rh-negative pregnant women.

Indications for Anti–D prophylaxis include:

1. All Rh-negative women should be offered Anti-D (unless RhD-negative women who have had free fetal DNA screening (cffDNA) and given a result which predicts the fetal group as negative. If such women still request Anti-D they should be offered).

First trimester indications:

  • Chorionic villus sampling
  • Miscarriage
  • Termination of pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy

Second-trimester & third-trimester indications

  • Amniocentesis, Cordocentesis
  • Obstetric haemorrhage
  • Abdominal trauma
  • External cephalic version

2. All Rh D-negative women should be given a single dose of 1500 units (300 mcg) of anti-D between 28 - 30 weeks of pregnancy.

3. Postnatally within 72 hours (300 mcg)

4. All women who deliver Rh D-positive baby should have a quantification of fetomaternal haemorrhage to guide the appropriate dose of anti-D prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: A young patient presents with a 1.5 cm, soft, non-tender, midline neck mass. It moves on protrusion of the tongue; there are no other neck masses. What is the most likely cause of the swelling?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. It is a midline neck mass that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood and is caused by the persistence of the thyroglossal tract (an embryological anomaly).

A thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone is not yet formed and the track may pass in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid bone.  

It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct:

  • Infrahyoid (most common site)
  • Region of thyroid cartilage
  • Suprahyoid
  • Floor of mouth
  • Beneath foramen cecum

The cyst moves on swallowing (because of its attachment to the hyoid bone) and on tongue protrusion (because of attachment to foramen cecum of the tongue). The swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and shows transillumination. The most common complication is infection. Its treatment is surgical excision (Sistrunk operation) of the whole thyroglossal tract, including removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract.

questions.text: As an intern you are told to examine a patient diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. Which of the following best describes this condition?

choices.text: Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons
Abnormally dense bone due to defective osteoclast

questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Below is an image of a patient with Kienböck's disease in the left hand.


Other options:

Option B:  Stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons is seen in De Quervain's disease.

Option C: Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Option D:  Abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation due to defective osteoclast function is seen in osteopetrosis. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: Stimulating which of the following hypothalamic nuclei will lead to increased appetite?
questions.solution:
Stimulating lateral hypothalamic nuclei is will lead to increased appetite and food intake. 

The lateral hypothalamus is generally known as the hunger center, and its main function is the stimulation of feeding behavior and appetite. Excessive stimulation of these nuclei causes a voracious appetite, whereas any lesion here produces a profound loss of appetite, weight loss, and decreased metabolism.  

Other options - 

Option A - Ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus, also known as the satiety center gives a sense of satisfaction or fullness and inhibits the feeding center. 

Option C - Anterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature. 

Option D - Suprachiasmatic nucleus controls the diurnal variation of ACTH, and also regulates the circadian rhythm.

questions.text: A patient is posted for surgery of a distal forearm fracture. Regional anesthesia was planned. The drug is injected intravenously into a tourniquet occluded limb. Which of the following is not true for the type of anesthesia being used here?

choices.text: Providing a bloodless field is difficult
Prilocaine is commonly used in this type of block
Exsanguination is done prior to tourniquet inflation
Bupivacaine is the drug of choice in this method

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the block being done is intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) or the Bier's block. Bupivacaine is not the drug of choice in IVRA due to its severe local anesthetic side effects.

Bier's block is used to provide regional anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<60 minutes) of the limbs. It involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet–occluded limb. Anesthesia sets in within 5 minutes. 

The limb is first raised above the heart level to drain venous blood. Then exsanguination is done by applying an Esmarch bandage, following which a tourniquet is applied proximally to the site of the operative procedure. The solution is injected and usually left in place for at least 25 minutes, after which the tourniquet is released incrementally. Drugs commonly used are lidocaine and prilocaine.

The patient is observed for any signs or symptoms of local anesthetic toxicity. The local anesthetic diffuses from the peripheral vascular bed to nonvascular tissue such as axons and nerve endings. The safety and efficacy of this procedure depend on the interruption of blood flow to the involved limb and the gradual release of the tourniquet. 

Complications following Bier's block are postoperative pain, difficulty in providing bloodless field, and in rare cases may lead to compartment syndrome due to increased pressure applied. Premature deflation of the tourniquet or increased dose of local anesthesia may lead to systemic toxicity.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive ataxia and recurrent respiratory infections. His skin is wrinkled and he has a vascular, tortuous rash on his face and ears. He has a lesion in his eye as shown below. Which of the following DNA repair pathways is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
These clinical features are characteristic of Ataxia telangiectasia(AT); a combined immunodeficiency disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. In AT, there is defective homologous recombination.

Homologous recombination uses an undamaged DNA as a template and repairs the break, leading to the reconstitution of the original sequence . A mutation of the ATM gene is responsible for improper repairing of the breaks of double-strand DNA. Because of this defect, cell response to different pathogenic triggers, such as ionizing radiation and alkylating agents is impaired.

The ATM gene, which is found on chromosome 11, is mutated in ataxia telangiectasia. Additionally, poor Ig isotype switching and antigen receptor development are also seen. Thus, live vaccinations are avoided because the patient has a partial T cell deficit and is immunodeficient.

Cerebral ataxia, telangiectasia, ovarian dysgenesis, and chromosomal abnormalities are the hallmarks of this illness. The face, conjunctiva, and other body parts are affected by telangiectasia, which often first manifests at the age of five or six. Early-life recurring sinopulmonary infections or cancer in the second or third decade of life are the causes of death. They also have a higher chance of getting lymphomas and leukaemias. Replacement immunoglobulins are part of the treatment. 

Other options:

Option A: Nucleotide excision repair (NER): a DNA repair pathway that repairs damage caused by ultraviolet radiation. Defects in NER can cause xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme photosensitivity.

Option C: A base excision repair defect is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis syndrome.

Option D: Mismatch repair (MMR): a DNA repair pathway that repairs errors that occur during DNA replication. Defects in MMR can cause Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipochrome (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. Lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin; it is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal aging patients.

Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes
  • Prominent in the liver, brain, and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.


Option C: Mallory bodies are seen in Indian childhood cirrhosis and Wilson’s disease.


Option D: Cholesterol deposits are seen in atherosclerosis and xanthomas.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist performs laparoscopy, during which he finds the following lesions in the pelvis. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given condition is endometriosis. The laparoscopic picture shows powder-burn spots pathognomic of endometriosis. Estrogen therapy is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as it is the major risk factor for the condition.

Treatment of endometriosis:

1. Medical management:

For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.

For moderate to severe diseases, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonist.

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

2. Surgical management:

Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy.

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

Risk factors for the development of endometriosis

  • Family history
  • Nulliparity
  • Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen (early menarche, late menopause)
  • Estrogen therapy
  • In utero exposure to diethylstilbesterol (DES)

Key clinical features

  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Infertility
  • Pain during urination or defecation
  • Constipation or diarrhea
  • Irregular bleeding

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis has been a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Laparoscopy helps detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis, locate the site of endometriosis and staging, take a biopsy, and perform surgical ablation as a part of treatment.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels: raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels: raised in the peritoneal fluid
  • MRI
  • Color Doppler
  • Anti-endometrial antibodies

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: What percentage of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel should be occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque to call it a stage of critical stenosis?
questions.solution:
70 - 75% of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel is occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque in the stage of critical stenosis.

In atherosclerotic stenosis, critical stenosis is the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This typically occurs when the occlusion produces a 70% to 75% decrease in luminal cross-sectional area. With this degree of stenosis in the coronary circulation, the patient may experience chest pain on exertion i.e, stable angina.

Critical stenosis also leads to bowel ischemia, intermittent claudication, mesenteric occlusion, sudden cardiac death, chronic ischemic heart disease and ischemic encephalopathy.

An increased level of LDL is directly associated with the development of coronary heart disease. This promotes the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, undergoing the following process.


An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as rupture, ulceration, erosion which lead to thrombus formation, or hemorrhage into the plaque which increases the plaque size. Both of these consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply.

Modifiable:

  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

Additional risk factors:

  • Inflammation 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] 
  • Elevated plasminogen activator inhibitor 1
  • Type A personality

questions.text: A man who had a fistfight with a neighbor was brought to you with a fracture of the lower central incisor and soft tissue injury to the area around his mouth. He also had contusions on his legs. What is the nature of this injury?
questions.solution:
Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth is categorized as grievous injury.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprise of any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Grievous hurt is a cognizable offence for which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from magistrate. (BNS Sec 116/320 IPC)

Punishment for grievous hurt :

  • BNS Sec 117(2): Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
  • BNS Sec 118(2) Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—minimum imprisonment of 1 year, extendable up to 10 years and fine.

questions.text: The ICDS department carried out a nutritional survey of a group of children in the town. The length-for-age of an 18-month-old girl baby is shown as 'X' in the image below. This growth chart indicates that the child has:
questions.solution:
The point X in the given WHO growth chart  (length for age) indicates that the child falls below -3SD and can therefore be classified to have chronic malnutrition/severe stunting.

Low height for the age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

questions.text:
A patient presents with rapidly progressive oliguria and edema following an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis 2 weeks ago. His urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Serum creatinine is 4.0 mg/dL. Renal biopsy shows the presence of crescents. What is the likely diagnosis?

RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with oliguria, edema, with an elevated serum creatinine, crescents on renal biopsy, and a past history of streptococcal pharyngitis, is suggestive of postinfectious glomerulonephritis. It is a type II RPGN mediated by immune-complex deposition. 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury. It is characterized by a rapid decline of renal function with severe oliguria. On histology, it is characterized by the presence of crescents in glomeruli. The crescents constrict the capillary tuft, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, thus causing acute kidney injury.


Type II RPGN is characterized by immune complex deposition. Immunofluorescence will reveal granular deposits of antibodies and complement. Examples of this type include RPGN due to postinfectious glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis, IgA nephropathy, or Henoch-Schönlein purpura.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the ASAS criteria for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Sacroiliitis on imaging, HLA-B27, and inflammatory back pain are all included in ASAS criteria for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). ESR is not a criterion for the diagnosis of AS and is nonspecifically elevated in most inflammatory conditions.

ESR is a nonspecific test that is elevated in a variety of conditions, including infection, cancer, and autoimmune diseases and is not a reliable criterion for the diagnosis of AS. 

The ASAS criteria for AS require either sacroiliitis on imaging OR HLA-B27, plus at least one other seronegative spondyloarthropathies (SpA) feature. 

Sacroiliitis is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. (Option B) Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker (About 85%). (Option D) There is also peripheral joint involvement - shoulder and hips as the disease progresses (presence indicates poor prognosis) (Option C)

The ASAS Criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients under 45 years of age with lower back pain of 3 months duration: 

  • Radiologic: Sacroiliitis (X-ray/MRI) and at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis needs to be confirmed.
  • Clinical: Positive HLA B27 and at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis being mandatory

Radiological diagnosis of sacroiliitis:

  • Active inflammation in the MRI is highly suggestive of sacroiliitis due to spondyloarthritis.
  • Radiological sacroiliitis is defined according to the New York criteria (grade >2 bilateral or grade 3 - 4 unilateral)

Features of spondyloarthritis include Low inflammatory pain, Arthritis, Enthesitis, Uveítis, Dactylitis, Psoriasis, Crohn/colitis, Good response to NSAID, Family history of spondyloarthropathy, HLA B27 and high CRP levels.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line treatment for AS. For patients not responding to NSAIDs, methotrexate, tumor necrosis factor inhibitors and interleukin-17A inhibitors are effective treatment options. These biologics can also slow the progression of the disease on X-rays. Corticosteroids have minimal impact on the arthritis and spondylitis of AS and can worsen osteopenia and should not be used as a first-line treatment. Exercise is important for mobility in patients with AS.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes with complaints of floaters and flashes for the past 1 month. He wears -6D and -9D glasses in both eyes and denies any recent eye injury.  What should be the next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a person with -6D and -9D glasses is suggestive of severe myopia and along with the appearance of flashes and floaters, suggests the potential occurrence of peripheral retinal tears which can be evaluated in this patient with an indirect ophthalmoscope in preference to a direct ophthalmoscope as the field of view is larger in the former.

When examining floaters and flashes, indirect ophthalmoscopy is the best option for a comprehensive assessment of the entire retina. Peripheral retinal tears have a higher chance of developing into rhegmatogenous retinal detachments if they are not treated. Laser barrage is employed as a therapeutic intervention for the management of peripheral retinal tears.

The principle of indirect ophthalmoscope is to make the eye highly myopic. Light is transmitted from the headset to the fundus through a condensing lens held at the focal point of the eye, providing an inverted image that is observed through a stereoscopic viewing system.

Following are some of the features of an indirect ophthalmoscope:

  • A convex lens is used, commonly +20D.
  • The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified.
  • It allows you to view up to the retinal periphery.
  • It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions.

Other options:

Option A: Gonioscopy is used to evaluate the angle in cases of glaucoma. 

Option B: Retinoscopy is an objective method used to determine the error of refraction by applying the method of neutralization. It is also called skiascopy or shadow test. 

Option C: Direct ophthalmoscope has a very high magnification. However, the field of view of a direct ophthalmoscope is limited only to the central retina (disc and macula).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about medulloblastomas is incorrect?

choices.text: Most common childhood embryonal CNS tumor
Homer Wright rosettes are seen in this condition
It is a tumor arising from the posterior fossa
Rosenthal fibers are seen in this condition

questions.solution:
The statement in option D is incorrect. Rosenthal fibers are seen in pilocytic astrocytomas. They are astrocytic cytoplasmic inclusions that appear as elongated corkscrew-like structures that stain bright pink (eosinophilic).  

Medulloblastomas are embryonal tumors, also known as primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNET). This group is the most common group of malignant CNS tumors in childhood. Medulloblastomas consist of 90% of the embryonal CNS tumors (Option A). Other tumors belonging to this group include supratentorial PNET, ependymoblastoma, medulloepithelioblastima, and atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors. This group is graded as World Health Organization grade IV tumors. 

Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in males, presenting at a median age between 5-7 years of age. 

Clinical features include increased intracranial pressure manifesting as headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, hypertension. There is also cerebellar dysfunction which manifests as ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. 

Histologically, there is the presence of Homer Wright rosettes (Option B) and synaptophysin immunopositivity. There are multiple histological patterns, but the most common is a monomorphic sheet of undifferentiated cells noted as small, blue, round cells. 

CT and MRI will reveal a solid, homogenous, contrast medium enhancing mass in the posterior fossa (Option C). It can lead to obstruction of the 4th ventricle and hydrocephalus.

It is staged according to the Chang staging system and is treated with a multimodality approach, incorporating surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A researcher is planning a case-control study to investigate the association between exposure to a new drug and the development of a side effect. What can be done to reduce recall bias in this study?

choices.text: Decrease the time from exposure to follow-up
Stratify cases and controls based on risk factors
Avoid leading questions during the interview
Use a self-administered questionnaire to assess exposure history

questions.solution:
Decreasing the time from exposure to follow-up can reduce recall bias in case-control studies.

Recall bias is a form of bias that may arise in case-control studies when individuals with the condition (cases) are more inclined than those without the condition (controls) to remember previous exposures related to the outcome under investigation. This may occur because cases might be more motivated to reflect on their past exposures or have a greater tendency to recall exposures they believe could be linked to their illness.

To reduce recall bias, one effective strategy is to minimize the interval between exposure and follow-up. This is because the more time that passes between exposure and follow-up, the lower the likelihood that both cases and controls can precisely remember their previous exposures.

Other options:

Option B: Stratifying cases and controls based on risk factors does not reduce recall bias; instead, stratification is employed to reduce confounding bias.

Option C: Avoiding asking leading questions and ensuring consistent questioning for both cases and controls by interviewers can help reduce interviewer bias. However, it may not necessarily address recall bias.

Option D: Using a self-administered questionnaire to assess exposure history can be a convenient way to collect data. However, it may increase the risk of recall bias, as again, cases and controls may have different levels of motivation to complete the questionnaire accurately.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

Match the following antiretroviral drugs with their important adverse effects.
Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect

Option B is correctly matched.

Antiretroviral drug Adverse effect

1. Didanosine

c. Peripheral neuropathy

2. Abacavir

3. Indinavir

4. Enfuvirtide

Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV-1, HIV-2, and HTLV-1. Peripheral neuropathy characterized by pain, numbness, and tingling in glove and stock pattern, and pancreatitis are the most adverse effects of this drug. Stavudine, another NRTI, also causes similar adverse effects. 

Abacavir is also an NRTI approved for the treatment of HIV-1 infection. The most serious adverse effect of abacavir is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor that has a unique adverse effect of nephrolithiasis and crystalluria. It is also associated with asymptomatic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance.

Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor that binds to the transmembrane gp41 of HIV-1 and blocks its entry into the host cells. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, induration, and nodules/cysts development are most frequently seen.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with a rash shown in the image below. The onset was insidious and the rashes are mildly itchy. Wood's lamp shows pale yellow fluorescence. Microscopy of the causative organism would show which of the following morphological features?

choices.text: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image are of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. It is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species which on microscopic examination shows the presence of yeasts and hyphae in skin scrapings.

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause degradation of lipids producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor are-

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

Clinically, Tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They are mildly itchy if at all and have fine scales that are branny/furfuraceous.

Under Wood's lamp examination, the lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence. On KOH mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ appearance or ‘bananas and grapes’ appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

The image attached below shows the classic spaghetti and meatballs appearance on KOH mount.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls are observed in chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Sulfur granules are observed in mycetoma infection.

Option D: Yeasts with capsules are characteristic of cryptococcosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 27-year-old IT professional has presented to you with intense watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. He took out his contact lens and applied eye lubricants to help alleviate his ailment, but it didn't provide any relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

Patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva. These are caused by the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment includes the removal of the offending cause. Mast cell stabilizers, such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine, which have combined antihistamine and mast cell–stabilizing effects, are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A: In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

Option B: In follicular conjunctivitis, follicles are seen. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer.

The image shows follicles.

Option D: In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of a pulse in a patient with aortic regurgitation?

choices.text: A pulse alternating between strong and weak beats
A pulse that drops >10 mm in inspiration

questions.solution:
A pulse with double peaks is most consistent with pulsus bisferens, which is a characteristic pulse finding in aortic regurgitation. 

Pulsus bisferiens is a pulse wave with two peaks separated by a distinct mid-systolic dip. Rapid left ventricular ejection results in an early component percussion wave. The late component tidal wave represents a reflected wave from the periphery due to an artery's recoil effect. It can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Other types of peripheral pulses seen in aortic regurgitation are: 

  • Water hummer /Corrigan's pulse collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls during late systole and diastole.
  • Quincke's pulse is seen when pressure is applied at the tip of the nail. It causes alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail.

Other options: 

Option B: Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus which is seen as a low amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.

Option C: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction. 

Option D: Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by a fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP)> 10 mm Hg during inspiration. It is seen in patients with: 

  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Obstructive lung disease and
  • Tension pneumothorax.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with 2 days of fever, headache, and confusion. Brudzinski and Kerning’s signs are positive. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings are as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?

WBCs: 100/μL; Lymphocytic pleocytosis
RBCs: 10,000/μL
Glucose: 60 mg/dL 
Protein: 150 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis as the CSF analysis shows a large amount of RBCs. 

HSV encephalitis is associated with hemorrhagic necrosis of inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe resulting in a significant number of RBCs in the CSF. It is caused by both HSV 1 and HSV 2. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality and behavioural changes.

CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels, presence of RBCs and normal glucose concentration. Of note, hyponatremia can serve as a predictive marker for encephalitis.

EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges. PCR amplification of viral DNA from the cerebrospinal fluid is the most sensitive means of detection and is recommended for the diagnosis of herpes meningitis or encephalitis. The drug of choice for the condition is IV Acyclovir for 10-14 days.

With prompt treatment, the mortality rate is approximately 20%. However, even with treatment, many patients experience long-term neurological sequelae, such as cognitive impairment, seizures, and movement disorders.

Other options:

Option A: The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis typically include a marked pleocytosis (elevated white blood cell count), elevated protein, and low glucose levels. The white blood cell count is usually predominantly neutrophilic.

Option B: CSF findings in tuberculous meningitis are similar to those of bacterial meningitis, but the pleocytosis is typically less pronounced. The white blood cell count is usually predominantly lymphocytic.

Option D: CSF findings in cryptococcal meningitis include pleocytosis with lymphocytic predominance, normal-low glucose, high protein and high opening pressure. Moreover, this is likely to be seen as an opportunistic infection in a patient with poorly controlled HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the poison derived from the seeds shown in the image?

choices.text: It can be used to produce fake bruises
The active principle of this poison is bhilawanol
It causes conjunctivitis when instilled in eyes
The fatal period is 48 to 72 hours.

questions.solution:
The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of S. anacardium. Its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol. Common names are oriental cashew, marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, and bhela. A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options:

Option A: The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

Option B: Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic pain and stiffness in the knees. X-ray of her knee is shown below. The patient is most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This patient's complaints of chronic joint discomfort and radiograph indicating the presence of subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and narrowing of the joint space strongly imply a diagnosis of osteoarthritis.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. The typical clinical features include chronic joint pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion, as well as radiographic findings of joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. 

Management of osteoarthritis often involves a combination of non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, such as weight management, physical therapy, analgesics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and intra-articular injections. In severe cases, joint replacement surgery may be considered to alleviate symptoms and improve joint function.

Other options:

Option A: Pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), is a type of arthritis that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joints. It can cause sudden and severe joint pain, swelling, and stiffness. While it can present with joint-specific symptoms, it does not typically manifest with the radiographic findings described in the case, ie subchondral cysts, osteophytes and sclerosis. Patients with pseudogout have chondrocalcinosis as depicted in the image below.

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the synovial membrane of the joints, leading to joint pain, stiffness, and swelling. While it can cause joint damage and deformity, it often presents with different radiographic findings, including erosions(key hallmark) and periarticular osteopenia. However, it is crucial to note that when treated, patients may develop underlying proliferation and resemble a radiograph of a patient with osteoarthritis, as illustrated in the image below.

Option D: Osteoporosis is a common metabolic bone disease characterized by a diffuse reduction in bone density due to a decrease in bone mass. It is typically asymptomatic until fractures occur. These fractures are commonly low trauma in nature, defined as a fall from standing height or less. A DEXA scan is the investigation of choice in diagnosing osteoporosis and the results are reported in terms of T-score, and a score of -2.5 or lower is defined as osteoporosis.

questions.text: While karyotyping a sample of cells to look for the presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the dividing cells are arrested in which phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
For karyotyping, dividing cells are arrested in the metaphase in the M-phase of the cell cycle.

Chromosomes isolated from cells during the metaphase stage of mitosis are chosen for karyotyping because, it is during metaphase that the chromosomes assume their characteristic condensed, discrete shape.

The cell cycle refers to the events surrounding eukaryotic DNA replication and cell division (mitosis). The period preceding DNA replication is called the Gap 1 phase (G1). DNA replication occurs during the synthesis (S) phase. Following DNA synthesis, there is the Gap 2 phase (G2) before mitosis occurs (M). Cells that have stopped dividing, for example, T lymphocytes, have gone out of the cell cycle into the G0 phase.

There are five stages in mitosis namely prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. These occur in strictly sequential order. In metaphase, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere. Hence, in metaphase chromosomes can be visualized clearly during karyotyping.

The image given below shows different phases of the cell cycle:


Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who underwent permanent sterilization 5 years ago enquires about regaining her fertility. Which of the following procedures will allow for a reversal?
questions.solution:
The Uchida method involves minimal excision of the tube and hence preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

In the Uchida method, the serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube and then excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Essure permanent device (Option A) is a method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It consists of a micro-inserter with a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). It acts by benign local fibrous tissue growth leading to occlusion of the tube. The failure rate is 3.5%. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and the procedure can be done under local anesthesia.

Disadvantages of essure include the need for hysteroscopy, high cost, requirement of expertise, irreversibility, 3 months waiting time to ensure sterility, difficulty in bilateral insertion due to spasm and risk of tubal perforation.

Kroener's method (Option B) refers to fimbriectomy. It is done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by resection. Excision of fimbriae is irreversible.

In the Irving method (Option D), the mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the portion in between is excised. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament.

It is irreversible.

questions.text: Conley’s pointer is related to:
questions.solution:
Conley’s pointer is one of the anatomical landmarks for identification of facial nerve during superficial parotidectomy.

It refers to the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal and facial nerve lies 1 cm deep and inferior to it.
